title: staRburst Architecture
text: staRburst future backend enables seamless execution parallel R workloads AWS Fargate. handles environment synchronization, data transfer, quota management, worker orchestration automatically.

title: staRburst Architecture
text: Simplicity First: Fargate EC2, reasonable defaults configuration Leverage Existing Standards: Built future framework, uses standard R tools (renv) Fail Gracefully: Wave-based execution quota-limited, clear error messages Cost Transparent: Always show estimated actual costs Zero Babysitting: Auto-cleanup, auto-shutdown, automatic retries

title: staRburst Architecture
text: Challenge: Ensure worker R environments match local Solution: renv + Docker + Caching Performance: - First run: 5-10 min (build Docker image) - Subsequent runs: <10 sec (cached image) - rebuilds packages change
code: 1. Local renv snapshot    ‚îî‚îÄ> renv.lock file (exact package versions)  2. Docker image build    ‚îú‚îÄ> Base: rocker/r-ver:4.3.0    ‚îú‚îÄ> Install system deps    ‚îú‚îÄ> renv::restore(renv.lock)    ‚îî‚îÄ> Add worker script  3. ECR caching    ‚îú‚îÄ> Tag: starburst-{hash(renv.lock)}    ‚îú‚îÄ> If exists: pull    ‚îî‚îÄ> If new: build and push

title: staRburst Architecture
text: Submission: Worker Execution: Result Collection:
code: # User code f <- future({ expensive_computation(x) })  # Behind the scenes: 1. Capture expression and dependencies    expr <- quote({ expensive_computation(x) })    deps <- list(x = x, expensive_computation = expensive_computation)  2. Serialize to S3    task_id <- uuid::UUIDgenerate()    qs::qsave(list(expr = expr, deps = deps),               sprintf("s3://bucket/tasks/%s.qs", task_id))  3. Submit Fargate task    ecs_run_task(      taskDefinition = "starburst-worker",      environment = list(        TASK_ID = task_id,        S3_BUCKET = bucket      )    )  4. Return future object    future_obj <- list(      task_id = task_id,      submitted_at = Sys.time(),      state = "running"    ) # Worker container entrypoint main <- function() {   # Get task info from environment   task_id <- Sys.getenv("TASK_ID")   bucket <- Sys.getenv("S3_BUCKET")      # Download task   task <- qs::qread(sprintf("s3://%s/tasks/%s.qs", bucket, task_id))      # Restore environment   for (name in names(task$deps)) {     assign(name, task$deps[[name]], envir = .GlobalEnv)   }      # Execute   result <- tryCatch({     eval(task$expr, envir = .GlobalEnv)   }, error = function(e) {     list(error = TRUE, message = e$message)   })      # Upload result   qs::qsave(result, sprintf("s3://%s/results/%s.qs", bucket, task_id))      # Exit   quit(status = 0) }  main() # value(future) implementation value.starburst <- function(future, ...) {   # Poll for result   while (!result_exists(future$task_id)) {     Sys.sleep(1)   }      # Download result   result <- qs::qread(     sprintf("s3://%s/results/%s.qs", bucket, future$task_id)   )      # Handle errors   if (is.list(result) && isTRUE(result$error)) {     stop(result$message)   }      # Cleanup   delete_task_files(future$task_id)      result }

title: staRburst Architecture
text: Proactive Checking: Wave Execution:
code: plan.starburst <- function(workers, cpu, ...) {   # Check quota before doing anything   quota <- get_fargate_quota()   needed <- workers * cpu      if (needed > quota$limit) {     # Calculate wave execution     workers_per_wave <- floor(quota$limit / cpu)     num_waves <- ceiling(workers / workers_per_wave)          # Inform user     message(sprintf(       "Quota allows %d workers, running in %d waves",       workers_per_wave, num_waves     ))          # Offer quota increase     if (interactive() && !quota$increase_pending) {       if (ask_user("Request quota increase?")) {         request_quota_increase(suggest_quota(needed))       }     }          # Create wave-based plan     return(create_wave_plan(workers, workers_per_wave, num_waves))   }      # Sufficient quota - normal plan   create_plan(workers, cpu) } execute_with_waves <- function(tasks, plan) {   results <- vector("list", length(tasks))   completed <- 0      for (wave in seq_len(plan$num_waves)) {     # Get tasks for this wave     start_idx <- completed + 1     end_idx <- min(completed + plan$workers_per_wave, length(tasks))     wave_tasks <- tasks[start_idx:end_idx]          message(sprintf("Wave %d/%d: %d tasks",                     wave, plan$num_waves, length(wave_tasks)))          # Submit wave     futures <- lapply(wave_tasks, submit_task)          # Collect results     wave_results <- lapply(futures, value)     results[start_idx:end_idx] <- wave_results          completed <- end_idx   }      results }

title: staRburst Architecture
text: Estimation: Actual Tracking:
code: estimate_cost <- function(workers, cpu, memory, estimated_runtime_sec) {   # Fargate pricing (us-east-1, as of 2025)   vcpu_price_per_hour <- 0.04048   gb_price_per_hour <- 0.004445      memory_gb <- parse_memory(memory)      cost_per_hour <-      (cpu * vcpu_price_per_hour) +      (memory_gb * gb_price_per_hour)      total_cost <- cost_per_hour * workers * (estimated_runtime_sec / 3600)      list(     per_hour = cost_per_hour,     total = total_cost,     workers = workers   ) } track_cost <- function(cluster_id) {   # Query CloudWatch for actual runtime   tasks <- list_tasks(cluster_id)      total_cost <- 0   for (task in tasks) {     runtime_sec <- difftime(task$stopped_at, task$started_at, units = "secs")     task_cost <- calculate_task_cost(task$cpu, task$memory, runtime_sec)     total_cost <- total_cost + task_cost   }      total_cost }

title: staRburst Architecture
text: Worker Failures: Partial Results:
code: submit_task_with_retry <- function(task, max_retries = 3) {   for (attempt in seq_len(max_retries)) {     tryCatch({       future <- submit_task(task)       return(future)     }, error = function(e) {       if (attempt == max_retries) stop(e)       message(sprintf("Retry %d/%d: %s", attempt, max_retries, e$message))       Sys.sleep(2^attempt)  # Exponential backoff     })   } } # Save results as they complete collect_results_progressive <- function(futures) {   results <- vector("list", length(futures))      for (i in seq_along(futures)) {     tryCatch({       results[[i]] <- value(futures[[i]])       # Save checkpoint       save_checkpoint(results, i)     }, error = function(e) {       warning(sprintf("Task %d failed: %s", i, e$message))       results[[i]] <- NULL     })   }      results }

title: staRburst Architecture
code: # Choose serialization based on object type serialize_smart <- function(obj) {   if (is.data.frame(obj) && nrow(obj) > 10000) {     # Large data frames: Arrow     arrow::write_parquet(obj, tempfile())   } else if (is_large_object(obj)) {     # Large R objects: qs (fast compression)     qs::qsave(obj, tempfile(), preset = "fast")   } else {     # Small objects: base serialize     serialize(obj, NULL)   } }

title: staRburst Architecture
code: # Parallel multipart upload for large objects upload_to_s3 <- function(file, bucket, key) {   file_size <- file.size(file)      if (file_size > 100 * 1024^2) {  # >100MB     # Use multipart upload     multipart_upload_parallel(file, bucket, key,                                part_size = 50 * 1024^2,                               num_threads = 4)   } else {     # Simple upload     put_object(file, bucket, key)   } }

title: staRburst Architecture
text: IAM Roles: - User: starburst-user permissions ECS, S3, ECR, Service Quotas - Task: starburst-worker-execution pulling images - Worker: starburst-worker-task S3 access S3 Bucket: - Private default - Encryption rest (SSE-S3) - Lifecycle policy: delete 7 days - Access logging enabled Network: - Workers private subnets (NAT gateway S3/ECR access) - Security groups: egress AWS services - SSH access containers

title: staRburst Architecture
text: CloudWatch Logs: Task Status: Debug Mode:
code: # View worker logs starburst_logs(task_id = "12345") starburst_logs(cluster_id = "cluster-67890", last_n = 100) # Check running tasks starburst_status() # > 3 workers running # > 47 tasks completed # > 0 tasks failed # > Est. cost so far: $2.34 # Keep workers alive for debugging plan(future_starburst, workers = 1, debug = TRUE) # Workers stay alive, can SSH via AWS Session Manager

title: staRburst Architecture
text: Overhead Analysis (100 workers, 4 vCPU ): Crossover Point: - Local task time: 1 min ‚Üí worth cloud (overhead = 56s) - Local task time: 5 min ‚Üí Marginal (overhead = 19%) - Local task time: 30 min ‚Üí Clear win (overhead = 3%) Scalability: - 10 workers: Linear overhead - 100 workers: Linear overhead (wave-based quota-limited) - 1000 workers: Requires quota increase, linear overhead waves

title: staRburst Architecture

text: Implementation: EC2 Spot Fleet interruption handling checkpointing.
code: plan(future_starburst,      workers = 100,      spot = TRUE,  # Use spot instances      max_price = 0.05)  # Bid price

title: staRburst Architecture

title: Detached Session Mode - Implementation Summary
text: Core S3 operations session state persistence: Functions: - create_session_manifest() - Initialize session S3 full backend config - update_session_manifest() - Update session metadata stats - get_session_manifest() - Load session S3 - create_task_status() - Create task status file (pending/claimed/running/completed/failed) - update_task_status() - Update status optional atomic ETag check - get_task_status() - Get task status optional ETag atomic operations - list_pending_tasks() - Find pending tasks session - list_task_statuses() - Get task statuses collection - atomic_claim_task() - High-level atomic task claiming helper Key Implementation Details: - Uses S3 ETags atomic conditional writes (prevents race conditions) - Task lifecycle: pending ‚Üí claimed ‚Üí running ‚Üí completed|failed - Session manifest stores full backend configuration reattachment - Task statuses track timestamps worker IDs

title: Detached Session Mode - Implementation Summary
text: Backend management detached sessions: Functions: - initialize_detached_backend() - Create backend without modifying future plan - launch_detached_workers() - Launch workers bootstrap tasks - upload_detached_task() - Upload task data S3 - submit_detached_worker() - Submit ECS task worker - reconstruct_backend_from_manifest() - Rebuild backend reattaching Key Implementation Details: - Backend stores session_id mode = "detached" - Creates session manifest initialization - Launches bootstrap tasks tell workers session ID - Bootstrap tasks trigger worker polling mode - Supports FARGATE EC2 launch types - Handles warm pool management EC2

title: Detached Session Mode - Implementation Summary
text: Public API detached sessions: Exported Functions: - starburst_session() - Create new detached session - starburst_session_attach() - Reattach existing session - starburst_list_sessions() - List sessions S3 - print.StarburstSessionStatus() - Pretty print session status Session Object Methods: - session$submit(expr, ...) - Submit task session - session$status() - Get progress summary - session$collect(wait = FALSE) - Collect completed results - session$extend(seconds = 3600) - Extend timeout - session$cleanup() - Terminate cleanup Key Implementation Details: - Session object R environment methods - submit() auto-detects globals packages like future - collect() supports blocking (wait = TRUE) non-blocking modes - Status aggregates task states S3 - Backend exposed directly user (encapsulated)

title: Detached Session Mode - Implementation Summary

title: Detached Session Mode - Implementation Summary
code: User: submit(expr)   ‚Üì [pending] Task status created in S3   ‚Üì Worker: Polls for pending tasks   ‚Üì [claimed] Atomic S3 conditional write (ETag)   ‚Üì [running] Worker executing task   ‚Üì [completed] Result uploaded to S3

title: Detached Session Mode - Implementation Summary
text: Detached Mode: 1. Download bootstrap task 2. Detect task$session_id ‚Üí enter polling mode 3. Poll S3 pending tasks (exponential backoff) 4. Atomically claim task (ETag-based) 5. Download task, execute, upload result 6. Update status completed 7. Reset backoff, continue polling 8. Exit 5 min idle Ephemeral Mode (unchanged): 1. Download task 2. Execute 3. Upload result 4. Exit

title: Detached Session Mode - Implementation Summary
text: Works: Failure Modes: - another worker modified status: PreconditionFailed error - Worker catches error tries next pending task - duplicate execution, task loss
code: # 1. Get current status WITH ETag response <- s3$get_object(Bucket, Key) etag <- response$ETag status <- parse(response$Body)  # 2. Check if pending if (status$state != "pending") return FALSE  # 3. Modify status status$state <- "claimed" status$claimed_by <- worker_id status$claimed_at <- Sys.time()  # 4. Conditional PUT - only succeeds if ETag unchanged s3$put_object(   Bucket = bucket,   Key = key,   Body = status,   IfMatch = etag  # ‚Üê ATOMIC: fails if another worker claimed it )

what: Detached Sessions - Issues and Weaknesses Report
title: Detached Sessions - Issues and Weaknesses Report
text: Generated: 2026-02-11

what: 1. No Error Handling in Worker Task Execution ‚ö†Ô∏è CRITICAL
title: Detached Sessions - Issues and Weaknesses Report
text: Location: inst/templates/worker.R:228-258 Issue: executing tasks detached mode (Future format), ‚Äôs try-catch around eval() call. task throws error, worker crash instead marking task failed. Impact: - Workers crash task error - Task stays ‚Äúrunning‚Äù state forever - error information captured - Session becomes unrecoverable Fix Required: Priority: CRITICAL - Must fix production use
code: # Current code (lines 228-258): } else if (!is.null(task$expr)) {     # NEW FORMAT: Future-based execution     message("Task loaded (Future format)")     message("Executing task...")      # ... setup code ...      # Evaluate expression - NO ERROR HANDLING!     result_value <- eval(task$expr, envir = exec_env)      result <- list(       error = FALSE,       value = result_value,       stdout = "",       conditions = list()     ) } result <- tryCatch({   result_value <- eval(task$expr, envir = exec_env)   list(     error = FALSE,     value = result_value,     stdout = "",     conditions = list()   ) }, error = function(e) {   list(     error = TRUE,     message = e$message,     value = NULL,     stdout = "",     conditions = list()   ) })

what: 2. No CloudWatch Logging for Detached Sessions ‚ö†Ô∏è HIGH
title: Detached Sessions - Issues and Weaknesses Report
text: Location: Task definition creation R/utils.R Issue: CloudWatch logging configured ephemeral mode verified detached sessions. Without logs, debugging worker failures nearly impossible. Current State: - Logging configuration exists R/utils.R:1295-1300 - tested detached sessions - log group verification session creation Impact: - debug worker crashes - visibility task execution - Difficult diagnose S3 access issues - Poor operational visibility Fix Required: 1. Add log group creation initialize_detached_backend() 2. Test CloudWatch logging detached workers 3. Add log stream querying session$status() recent errors 4. Document access logs Priority: HIGH

what: 3. Race Condition in Manifest Updates ‚ö†Ô∏è MEDIUM
title: Detached Sessions - Issues and Weaknesses Report
text: Location: R/session-state.R:78-118 - update_session_manifest() Issue: manifest update atomic. downloads, modifies, uploads without using ETags conditional writes. Multiple concurrent updates can result lost writes. Scenario: 1. User calls session$submit() ‚Üí updates manifest (total_tasks = 5) 2. Simultaneously, another submit() updates manifest (total_tasks = 6) 3. One update overwrites 4. Task count becomes incorrect Impact: - Incorrect task statistics - Potential data loss manifest - Hard detect/debug Fix Required: Implement ETag-based atomic updates similar task claiming: Priority: MEDIUM (low probability high impact)
code: update_session_manifest <- function(session_id, updates, region, bucket) {   # Download current manifest   s3$download_file(...)   manifest <- qs::qread(temp_file)    # Apply updates   for (name in names(updates)) {     manifest[[name]] <- updates[[name]]  # RACE CONDITION HERE   }    # Upload (unconditionally!)   s3$put_object(...)  # No ETag check! } # Get current manifest WITH ETag response <- s3$get_object(Bucket = bucket, Key = manifest_key) etag <- response$ETag manifest <- qs::qread(response$Body)  # Apply updates # ...  # Conditional PUT s3$put_object(   Bucket = bucket,   Key = manifest_key,   Body = temp_file,   IfMatch = etag  # Atomic! )

title: Detached Sessions - Issues and Weaknesses Report
text: Location: R/session-api.R:497-513 - cleanup_session() Issue: cleanup function almost nothing: - Doesn‚Äôt stop running workers - Doesn‚Äôt delete S3 files - Doesn‚Äôt provide forced termination option - Just prints message Impact: - Workers continue running 5 minutes idle timeout - S3 files accumulate indefinitely - way force-stop misbehaving sessions - Costs continue even ‚Äúcleanup‚Äù Fix Required: 1. Add ECS task termination: - Track worker task ARNs manifest - Call ecs$stop_task() worker 2. Add optional S3 cleanup: - Parameter delete_files = FALSE safety - TRUE, delete session S3 directory 3. Add manifest cleanup marker: - Mark session ‚Äúterminated‚Äù manifest - Workers check flag exit immediately Priority: HIGH
code: cleanup_session <- function(session) {   # Stop any running tasks (optional - they will time out naturally)   # For now, just mark session as cleaned up    # Could delete S3 files if desired   # For safety, we'll leave them for manual cleanup    cat_success("‚úì Session marked for cleanup\n")   cat_info("   Workers will self-terminate after idle timeout\n")   # ... that's it! }

what: 5. No Failed Task Handling in Results Collection ‚ö†Ô∏è MEDIUM
title: Detached Sessions - Issues and Weaknesses Report
text: Location: R/session-api.R:393-471 - collect_session_results() Issue: collection function looks state == "completed". Failed tasks completely ignored. Impact: - Failed tasks silently disappear - User doesn‚Äôt know tasks failed - error information available - Silent data loss Fix Required: Priority: MEDIUM
code: # Skip if not completed or already collected if (status$state != "completed" || task_id %in% names(results)) {   next  # Failed tasks are skipped! } # Collect both completed and failed results if (status$state == "completed") {   # Download result normally } else if (status$state == "failed") {   # Create error result object   results[[task_id]] <- list(     error = TRUE,     message = status$error_message,     failed_at = status$failed_at   ) }

what: 9. No Task Result Size Limits ‚ö†Ô∏è MEDIUM
title: Detached Sessions - Issues and Weaknesses Report
text: Location: inst/templates/worker.R:268-283 - upload_result() Issue: check result size uploading S3. Large results cause memory issues S3 upload failures. Impact: - Worker crashes large results - S3 upload timeouts - Hidden memory exhaustion - user guidance result size Fix Required: Priority: MEDIUM
code: upload_result <- function(result, task_id, s3, bucket) {   result_file <- tempfile(fileext = ".qs")   qs::qsave(result, result_file)    # Check size   size_mb <- file.size(result_file) / 1024^2   if (size_mb > 500) {  # 500 MB limit     warning(sprintf("Result size %.1f MB exceeds recommended limit of 500 MB", size_mb))     # Consider chunking or streaming for large results   }    # Upload with progress   s3$put_object(...) }

title: Detached Sessions - Issues and Weaknesses Report
code: session <- starburst_session(workers = 50) lapply(1:1000, function(i) session$submit(quote(expensive_fn(i)))) results <- session$collect(wait = TRUE) ---  ### 13. **Incomplete Error Handling Examples** üìö MEDIUM  **Location:** `vignettes/detached-sessions.Rmd:145-170`  **Issue:** Error handling example shows checking `failed_task$error` but: - Doesn't explain how to get error messages - Doesn't show how to retry failed tasks - Doesn't explain failed task recovery  **Fix Required:** Expand example with: ```r # Find and retry failed tasks status <- session$status() if (status$failed > 0) {   # Get all statuses   all_statuses <- list_task_statuses(...)   failed_ids <- names(all_statuses)[sapply(all_statuses,     function(s) s$state == "failed")]    # Retry failed tasks   for (task_id in failed_ids) {     # Re-submit with original expression     session$submit(...)   } }

what: 14. No Cost Estimation for Detached Sessions üìö LOW
title: Detached Sessions - Issues and Weaknesses Report
text: Issue: Vignette doesn‚Äôt explain cost model detached sessions: - Workers running 24/7 idle timeout - Cost idle workers polling tasks - minimize costs Fix Required: Add section: Priority: HIGH
code: ## Cost Management  Detached sessions have different cost characteristics:  - **Workers poll continuously**: Even when idle, workers consume resources - **Idle timeout**: Workers auto-terminate after 5 minutes idle - **Cost optimization**: Start with fewer workers, submit in batches - **Estimated costs**: $0.05-0.10 per worker-hour (Fargate)  ### Best Practice: ```r # Instead of: session <- starburst_session(workers = 100)  # All running 24/7!  # Do this: session <- starburst_session(workers = 10)   # Smaller pool # Submit work in batches as needed ---  ### 15. **No API Reference Documentation** üìö MEDIUM  **Issue:** No man pages for core functions: - `starburst_session()` - has roxygen but basic - `starburst_session_attach()` - no details - `starburst_list_sessions()` - no docs on return format - `session$submit()` - no parameter docs - `session$status()` - no return value docs - `session$collect()` - no wait/timeout behavior explained  **Fix Required:** Enhance roxygen documentation with: - Full parameter descriptions - Return value details - Usage examples - Related functions - See also links  ---  ## Testing Gaps  ### 16. **No Tests for Error Cases** ‚ö†Ô∏è HIGH  **Issue:** Test coverage is good for happy path (36/36 passing) but missing: - Worker crash recovery - S3 access failures - Network interruptions - Timeout handling - Failed task scenarios - Race conditions with multiple sessions - Concurrent submit operations  **Fix Required:** Add tests: ```r test_that("worker handles task execution errors gracefully", {   session <- starburst_session(workers = 1)   session$submit(quote(stop("Intentional error")))    Sys.sleep(60)   status <- session$status()    expect_equal(status$failed, 1)   expect_equal(status$completed, 0) })  test_that("concurrent submits don't lose tasks", {   # Stress test manifest updates })

title: Plan: Remove Fargate Support from staRburst
text: Goal: Simplify codebase removing Fargate support, keeping EC2. Rationale: - EC2 much faster cold start (<30s vs 10+ min) - EC2 provides instance type control (Graviton, spot, etc.) - EC2 cost-effective burst workloads - Fargate adds complexity without clear benefits use case Impact: Breaking change - users Fargate need migrate EC2

code: estimate_cost <- function(workers, cpu, memory,                          estimated_runtime_hours = 1,                          launch_type = "FARGATE",                          instance_type = NULL,                          use_spot = FALSE) {   if (launch_type == "FARGATE") {     # Fargate pricing...   } else {     # EC2 pricing...   } } estimate_cost <- function(workers,                          instance_type,                          estimated_runtime_hours = 1,                          use_spot = FALSE) {   # Only EC2 pricing   instance_price <- get_ec2_instance_price(instance_type, use_spot)   instances_needed <- ceiling(workers / get_instance_workers(instance_type))   total_cost <- instances_needed * instance_price * estimated_runtime_hours    list(     per_instance = instance_price,     instances_needed = instances_needed,     total_estimated = total_cost   ) }

title: Plan: Remove Fargate Support from staRburst
text: VERSION: require bumping v0.2.0 CHANGELOG.md entry:
code: ## v0.2.0 - BREAKING CHANGES  ### Removed - **Fargate support removed**: staRburst now uses EC2 exclusively for better performance and cost control   - `launch_type` parameter removed from `plan()`   - `starburst_setup_ec2()` merged into `starburst_setup()`  ### Migration Guide Existing users on Fargate must: 1. Run `starburst_setup()` to create EC2 infrastructure 2. Update `plan()` calls to include `instance_type` parameter 3. Rebuild Docker images (automatic on first run)  Example: ```r # OLD plan(starburst, workers = 50, launch_type = "FARGATE")  # NEW plan(starburst, workers = 50, instance_type = "c6a.large")

title: Plan: Remove Fargate Support from staRburst
text: 10x faster cold start: <30s vs 10+ min Fargate Better cost control: Choose instance types spot pricing Simpler codebase: Less complexity, easier maintain v0.2.0: Remove Fargate entirely (planned ) gives users time migrate, adds ~1 month timeline.
code: ---  ## Implementation Steps  ### Phase 1: Preparation (1 day) 1. Create migration branch: `git checkout -b remove-fargate` 2. Add deprecation warnings in current version 3. Update docs with migration guide 4. Release v0.1.1 with warnings  ### Phase 2: Core Removal (2 days) 1. Remove launch_type from plan.starburst() 2. Remove Fargate branches from submit_task() 3. Remove Fargate from task definitions 4. Simplify cleanup_cluster() 5. Update backend state  ### Phase 3: Cost & Setup (1 day) 6. Simplify estimate_cost() 7. Merge setup functions 8. Update configuration  ### Phase 4: Documentation (1 day) 9. Update README.md 10. Update all vignettes 11. Update examples 12. Update CHANGELOG.md  ### Phase 5: Testing (1 day) 13. Update test suite 14. Remove Fargate tests 15. Run full benchmark suite 16. Verify all examples work  ### Phase 6: Release (1 day) 17. Bump version to 0.2.0 18. Tag release 19. Update GitHub releases 20. Announce breaking change  **Total**: ~7 days  ---  ## Files to Modify  ### R Files - `R/plan-starburst.R` - Remove launch_type, simplify backend - `R/future-starburst.R` - Remove Fargate task submission - `R/utils.R` - Simplify cost estimation and task definitions - `R/setup.R` - Merge setup functions - `R/ec2-pool.R` - No changes needed (EC2-specific)  ### Documentation - `README.md` - `vignettes/getting-started.Rmd` - `vignettes/example-*.Rmd` (all) - `AWS_COST_MODEL.md` - `CHANGELOG.md` (new)  ### Examples - `examples/01-monte-carlo-portfolio.R` - `examples/02-bootstrap-confidence-intervals.R` - `examples/03-parallel-data-processing.R` - `examples/04-grid-search-tuning.R`  ### Tests - `tests/testthat/test-ec2-integration.R` - Keep - `tests/testthat/test-ec2-e2e.R` - Keep - Remove any Fargate-specific tests  ### Other - `DESCRIPTION` - Bump version to 0.2.0 - `test-comparison.R` - Remove Fargate mode - `benchmark-runner.R` - Remove Fargate mode  ---  ## Risk Mitigation  ### Risk: Breaking existing users **Mitigation**: - Clear migration guide - Deprecation warnings in v0.1.1 - Maintain v0.1.x branch for critical fixes  ### Risk: Missing edge cases **Mitigation**: - Comprehensive test suite before release - Beta testing with early adopters - Gradual rollout  ### Risk: Documentation gaps **Mitigation**: - Update all docs before code removal - Add migration examples - Update error messages to guide users  ---  ## Success Criteria  - [ ] All Fargate code removed - [ ] All tests passing with EC2 only - [ ] Documentation updated - [ ] Examples working - [ ] Migration guide complete - [ ] Benchmarks show performance improvement - [ ] Breaking changes clearly communicated  ---  ## Alternative: Deprecation Period  If we want to be more conservative:  **v0.1.1**: Add deprecation warnings ```r if (launch_type == "FARGATE") {   warning("Fargate support is deprecated and will be removed in v0.2.0. ",           "Please migrate to EC2. See migration guide: ",           "https://github.com/scttfrdmn/starburst/wiki/Fargate-to-EC2") }

title: staRburst Performance Guidelines
text: Based Real AWS Testing (2026-02-04)

title: staRburst Performance Guidelines
text: Cloud overhead: ~2-3 seconds per Fargate task Sweet spot: Tasks taking 2-5+ minutes Best speedup: Batch 100-1000 operations per worker task

title: staRburst Performance Guidelines
code: Work: 100 simulations √ó 0.0002s = 0.02s total Cloud overhead: 259s Result: Cloud SLOWER (0.00x speedup) Lesson: Individual tasks too fast

title: staRburst Performance Guidelines
code: Work: 200 API calls, 10 workers, 20 calls each Per-task work: ~10 seconds Per-task overhead: ~2-3 seconds Speedup: 1.24x (12% efficiency) Lesson: Batches still too small

title: staRburst Performance Guidelines
code: Work: 2000 API calls, 10 workers, 200 calls each Per-task work: ~100 seconds Per-task overhead: ~2-3 seconds Expected speedup: ~8-9x (80-90% efficiency) Lesson: Large batches overcome overhead

title: staRburst Performance Guidelines
text: Components: 1. Container startup: ~1-2 seconds 2. Data download S3: ~0.5 seconds 3. Result upload S3: ~0.5 seconds 4. Total: ~2-3 seconds Impact Task Duration: | Task Duration | Overhead % | Efficiency | |‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî|‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî|‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî| | 1 second | 200-300% | Negative | | 5 seconds | 40-60% | Poor | | 10 seconds | 20-30% | Moderate | | 30 seconds | 7-10% | Good | | 60 seconds | 3-5% | Excellent | | 300 seconds | 1% | Optimal |

title: staRburst Performance Guidelines
code: # Each number becomes a separate Fargate task # 1000 tasks √ó 2.5s overhead = 2500s wasted results <- starburst_map(   1:1000,   function(x) sqrt(x),  # 0.0001s of work   workers = 50 ) # Result: SLOWER than local

title: staRburst Performance Guidelines
code: # Batch into 50 groups of 20 # 50 tasks √ó 2.5s overhead = 125s # Each task does 20 calculations batches <- split(1:1000, ceiling(seq_along(1:1000) / 20))  process_batch <- function(numbers) {   lapply(numbers, sqrt) }  results <- starburst_map(   batches,   process_batch,   workers = 50 ) # Result: Good speedup

title: staRburst Performance Guidelines
text: 1. API Calls (batching) 2. Report Generation 3. Model Training 4. Data Processing
code: # 1000 API calls, 50 workers, 20 calls each # Per-task: ~10-20 seconds # Speedup: 3-5x # 50 reports, 25 workers, 2 reports each # Per-task: ~60-120 seconds # Speedup: 10-15x # 100 models, 50 workers, 2 models each # Per-task: ~120-300 seconds # Speedup: 15-25x # Process 1M rows, 20 workers, 50k rows each # Per-task: ~60-180 seconds # Speedup: 10-18x

title: staRburst Performance Guidelines
text: 1. Fast Iterations 2. Simple Calculations 3. Small Datasets
code: # Problem: Each iteration < 1 second # Solution: Batch 100-1000 per task # Problem: sqrt(), sum(), etc. # Solution: Combine with I/O or batch # Problem: < 1000 operations # Solution: Batch or not worth cloud

title: staRburst Performance Guidelines
text: Impact: Reduces overhead 2500s 125s
code: # Instead of 1 operation per task starburst_map(1:1000, fn, workers = 50)  # 1000 tasks  # Do 20 operations per task batches <- split(1:1000, ceiling(seq_along(1:1000) / 20)) starburst_map(batches, process_batch, workers = 50)  # 50 tasks

title: staRburst Performance Guidelines
text: Impact: Work time grows, overhead stays
code: # Make each iteration more substantial process_complex <- function(x) {   # Multiple operations   data <- fetch_data(x)   processed <- transform_data(data)   result <- analyze(processed)   return(result) }

title: staRburst Performance Guidelines
text: Impact: Reduces total overhead
code: # Too many workers for small workload starburst_map(1:100, fn, workers = 50)  # 2 items per worker  # Better: Match workers to data starburst_map(1:100, fn, workers = 10)  # 10 items per worker

title: staRburst Performance Guidelines
text: Test 1: Monte Carlo (Fast) - Duration: 4.3 minutes - Workers: 5 √ó 1 vCPU √ó 2GB - Cost: $0.02 - Speedup: 0.00x - Cost per unit speedup: ‚àû Test 2: API Calls (Small Batches) - Duration: 1.4 minutes - Workers: 10 √ó 1 vCPU √ó 2GB - Cost: $0.01 - Speedup: 1.24x - Cost per unit speedup: $0.008 Projected: API Calls (Large Batches) - Duration: 2 minutes - Workers: 10 √ó 1 vCPU √ó 2GB - Cost: $0.02 - Speedup: 8-9x - Cost per unit speedup: $0.002

title: staRburst Performance Guidelines
text: Example (10 workers, 2 vCPU, 4GB, 5 minutes):
code: Cost = Workers √ó vCPU √ó vCPU_rate √ó Hours +        Workers √ó GB √ó Memory_rate √ó Hours  Where (us-east-1):   vCPU_rate = $0.04048/hour   Memory_rate = $0.004445/GB/hour Cost = 10 √ó 2 √ó $0.04048 √ó (5/60) +        10 √ó 4 √ó $0.004445 √ó (5/60)      = $0.067 + $0.015      = $0.082

title: staRburst Performance Guidelines
text: Example: 10,000 simple calculations Recommendation: - Batch 100 groups 100 - Use 50 workers (2 batches ) - task: ~5-10 seconds - Expected: 3-5x speedup

title: staRburst Performance Guidelines
text: Example: 1,000 API calls (0.5-2s ) Recommendation: - Batch 50 groups 20 - Use 25 workers (2 batches ) - task: ~20-40 seconds - Expected: 8-12x speedup

title: staRburst Performance Guidelines
text: Example: 100 PDF reports (30-60s ) Recommendation: - Batch 25 groups 4 - Use 25 workers (1 batch ) - task: ~120-240 seconds - Expected: 15-20x speedup

title: staRburst Performance Guidelines
text: Example: 50 models (2-5 min ) Recommendation: - batching needed - Use 25-50 workers (1-2 models ) - task: ~120-600 seconds - Expected: 20-25x speedup

title: staRburst Performance Guidelines

title: staRburst Performance Guidelines
code: target_task_duration <- 60  # seconds (minimum recommended) overhead <- 3  # seconds per_item_time <- 0.5  # from profiling  batch_size <- ceiling((target_task_duration - overhead) / per_item_time) # Result: 114 items per batch

title: staRburst Performance Guidelines
code: total_items <- 1000 local_time <- total_items * per_item_time # 1000 √ó 0.5 = 500 seconds  n_workers <- 20 batches <- ceiling(total_items / batch_size) # ceiling(1000 / 114) = 9 batches  batches_per_worker <- ceiling(batches / n_workers) # ceiling(9 / 20) = 1 batch per worker  cloud_time <- (batch_size * per_item_time) + overhead # (114 √ó 0.5) + 3 = 60 seconds  speedup <- local_time / cloud_time # 500 / 60 = 8.3x

title: staRburst Performance Guidelines
code: # ‚ùå Bad: 10,000 tasks of 0.1s each starburst_map(1:10000, quick_fn, workers = 100) # Overhead: 25,000s, Work: 1,000s  # ‚úÖ Good: 100 tasks of 10s each starburst_map(batches, batch_fn, workers = 100) # Overhead: 250s, Work: 1,000s

title: staRburst Performance Guidelines
code: # ‚ùå Bad: More workers than tasks starburst_map(1:10, fn, workers = 50) # 40 workers sit idle  # ‚úÖ Good: Match workers to workload starburst_map(1:100, fn, workers = 25) # Each worker gets 4 tasks

title: staRburst Performance Guidelines
code: # ‚ùå Bad: Large data per task huge_data <- matrix(rnorm(1e7), ncol = 100) starburst_map(1:1000, function(x) process(huge_data, x)) # S3 transfer becomes bottleneck  # ‚úÖ Good: Generate data on workers starburst_map(1:1000, function(x) {   data <- generate_data(x)   process(data) })

title: staRburst Performance Guidelines
text: staRburst works best : 1. worker task runs 2+ minutes 2. processes 100-1000 operations batch 3. Work time significantly exceeds 3-second overhead Key success: Right-size batches! questions optimization help: help@starburst.ing

title: staRburst Profiling Plan
text: Goal: Understand ‚Äôre getting 1.5x speedup instead 5x+ 50 workers vs 10 cores Current Results: - Expected: ~5x (50 workers / 10 cores) - Actual: 1.5x - Gap: 3.3x missing performance

title: staRburst Profiling Plan
text: Observation: AWS Fargate tasks appear much slower per-core M4 Pro Potential Causes: - Default Fargate instances use Intel Skylake older (~2.5 GHz) - M4 Pro performance cores run 3.5-4.0 GHz better IPC - Different CPU architectures (x86 vs ARM) - AVX-512 optimizations Fargate measure: - ‚úÖ Profiling script (running now) - compare compute time per iteration - Run task different instance types (c7g, c7i, c6i) - Check actual CPU model cat /proc/cpuinfo worker - Benchmark single-threaded performance (LINPACK, etc.) Solutions try: - Use c7i instances (latest Intel, 3.5 GHz -core) - Use c7g Graviton3 (better ARM performance Fargate default) - Use c6i instances (older still better default Fargate) - Request vCPUs per task (4-8 vCPUs may get better instances)

title: staRburst Profiling Plan
text: Observation: First result took 21.6 min vs 11.6 min expected (10 min overhead) Potential Causes: - Docker image pull time (~2-5 min full image) - Container startup time (~1-2 min) - S3 data upload/download (~0.5-1 min) - Task scheduling queue time (~1-2 min) measure: - Add timestamps start worker execution - Measure time task submission first log - Track Docker pull time separately - Profile S3 transfer time small test data Solutions try: - Pre-pull images workers (warm pool) - Use smaller Docker images (multi-stage builds) - Use public ECR (faster pull private) - Increase concurrent task launches - Pre-warm ECS capacity

title: staRburst Profiling Plan
text: Observation: Last task took 46.5 min vs first 21.6 min (2.1x variance) Potential Causes: - Instance performance variation (get slower CPUs) - Resource contention (CPU, memory, network) - Thermal throttling instances - Unlucky scheduling (noisy neighbors) - Network variability S3 transfers measure: - ‚úÖ Profiling script - measure task--task variance - Log actual CPU model per worker - Monitor CPU throttling execution - Track network latency/bandwidth per worker - Histogram completion times Solutions try: - Speculative execution (launch 10% extra tasks, use first N) - Task splitting (break large tasks smaller chunks) - Better load balancing (dynamic task assignment) - Reserve instances (guaranteed performance) - Use placement groups (collocate workers)

title: staRburst Profiling Plan
text: Observation: Wall clock 46.5 min longest task ~40-42 min (estimated) Potential Causes: - ECS task scheduling delay - S3 result collection time - starburst_map polling overhead - Network round-trips measure: - Log wall clock vs longest task time - Profile S3 result download time - Measure ECS API latency - Track polling frequency/efficiency Solutions try: - Batch S3 downloads - Async result collection - Reduce polling frequency - Use EventBridge instead polling

title: staRburst Profiling Plan
text: Script: /tmp/profiling-monte-carlo.R Measures: - Local M4 Pro timing breakdown - Cloud timing breakdown (10 workers) - Per-task variance - Computation vs overhead split Expected Output: - Exact per-core performance ratio (AWS / M4 Pro) - Overhead per task - Task variance statistics

title: Real Science Examples - Publication-Grade Workloads
text: Scientific Domain: Bioinformatics, Population Genetics Workload: - 1,000 patient genomic samples - 50,000 variants per sample (SNPs, indels) - 20,000 genes - Total: 50 million variant calls Analyses Per Sample: 1. Allele frequency calculation 2. Hardy-Weinberg Equilibrium testing (1,000 variants) 3. Linkage Disequilibrium (500 variant pairs) 4. Gene-based association tests (5,000 genes) 5. Population stratification (PCA 1,000 variants) Computational Characteristics: - Heavy matrix operations - Statistical testing (chi-square, correlation) - Aggregations grouping - Per-sample time: ~30-60 seconds - Total sequential: ~10-15 hours Cloud Strategy: - Batch 10 samples per worker - 100 workers - worker: ~5-10 minutes - Expected speedup: 60-90x Real-World Application: - GWAS (Genome-Wide Association Studies) - Population genetics research - Clinical variant interpretation - Personalized medicine

title: Real Science Examples - Publication-Grade Workloads
text: Scientific Domain: Climate Science, Earth System Modeling Workload: - 500 climate model simulations (ensemble) - 100 years per simulation - 100√ó100 spatial grid (10,000 cells) - 4 variables: Temperature, Pressure, Humidity, Wind - Total: 5 billion cell-years Physical Processes: 1. Spatial diffusion (heat/pressure redistribution) 2. Coupled variable interactions 3. Forcing scenarios (CO‚ÇÇ, solar) 4. Annual decadal trend calculation 5. Extreme event detection Computational Characteristics: - Nested loops (years √ó months √ó spatial grid) - Neighbor averaging (convolution-like) - Time series analysis - Linear regression trends - Per-simulation time: ~3-5 minutes - Total sequential: ~25-40 hours Cloud Strategy: - Batch 5 simulations per worker - 100 workers - worker: ~15-25 minutes - Expected speedup: 60-100x Real-World Application: - IPCC climate projections - Regional climate modeling - Climate sensitivity studies - Uncertainty quantification

title: Real Science Examples - Publication-Grade Workloads
text: Scientific Domain: Computational Chemistry, Drug Discovery Workload: - 200 protein-ligand systems - 10,000 atoms per system - 100,000 timesteps (100 picoseconds) - Total: 200 trillion force calculations Physical Simulation: 1. Pairwise force calculations (Lennard-Jones) 2. Velocity Verlet integration 3. Periodic boundary conditions 4. Energy conservation monitoring 5. Structural analysis (radius gyration) Computational Characteristics: - N¬≤ complexity (pairwise interactions) - Pure CPU burn (minimal /O) - Floating-point intensive - Memory-intensive (atom positions/velocities) - Per-system time: ~5-10 minutes - Total sequential: ~15-30 hours Cloud Strategy: - Batch 2 systems per worker - 100 workers 4 vCPU - worker: ~10-20 minutes - Expected speedup: 50-90x Real-World Application: - Drug discovery (protein-ligand binding) - Protein folding studies - Material science simulations - Enzyme mechanism research

title: staRburst Testing Guide
code: # Manual cleanup script ./run-aws-tests.sh quick  # Runs cleanup in [6/6] step  # Or cleanup manually in R: Rscript -e "   devtools::load_all()    # Clean up sessions   sessions <- starburst_list_sessions()   for (id in names(sessions)) {     session <- starburst_session_attach(id)     session\$cleanup(force = TRUE)   }    # Stop orphaned tasks   config <- starburst_config()   ecs <- paws.compute::ecs(config = list(region = config\$region))   tasks <- ecs\$list_tasks(cluster = config\$cluster)   for (task in tasks\$taskArns) {     ecs\$stop_task(cluster = config\$cluster, task = task, reason = 'Manual cleanup')   } "

what: Integration Tests - Issue #2: Expression Capture Bug
title: Detached Sessions - Testing Summary
text: Test Command: Error Encountered: Root Cause: - users call session$submit(quote(* 2)), substitute() function capturing parameter symbol ‚Äúexpr‚Äù instead quoted expression value - Workers received tasks expression = symbol ‚Äúexpr‚Äù instead actual call ‚Äú* 2‚Äù - Workers crashed trying execute undefined symbol Fix Applied: Commit: 6bd35b3 - fix: Handle quoted expressions correctly exclude bootstrap tasks counts Changes made /R/session-api.R: Status: ‚úÖ Fixed committed
code: AWS_PROFILE=aws NOT_CRAN=true R -e "testthat::test_file('tests/testthat/test-detached-sessions.R')" Failure: session submit and collect workflow length(results) > 0 is not TRUE `actual`:   FALSE if (substitute) {   expr_sub <- base::substitute(expr)   # If substitute returns a symbol 'expr', it means the argument was already   # evaluated (e.g., user passed quote(...)). In that case, use the value.   if (is.symbol(expr_sub) && identical(as.character(expr_sub), "expr")) {     # expr is already evaluated, check if it's a language object     if (!is.language(expr)) {       stop("When substitute=TRUE and passing an evaluated expression, ",            "it must be a language object (e.g., created with quote())")     }     # Use the evaluated expression as-is   } else {     # Use the substituted expression     expr <- expr_sub   } }

title: When to Use Cloud vs Local: A Practical Guide
text: small (< 30 seconds per task): Sweet spot (2-10 minutes per task): large (> 30 minutes per task): Batching Strategy:
code: Work: 20 seconds Overhead: 2-3 seconds Overhead impact: 10-15% Work: 5 minutes = 300 seconds Overhead: 2-3 seconds Overhead impact: <1% Work: 60 minutes Problem: Stragglers hurt (one slow task delays everything) Solution: Split into smaller chunks # Bad: 10,000 tasks of 1 second each starburst_map(1:10000, quick_fn, workers = 100)  # Good: 100 tasks of 100 seconds each batches <- split(1:10000, ceiling(seq_along(1:10000)/100)) starburst_map(batches, batch_fn, workers = 100)

title: When to Use Cloud vs Local: A Practical Guide

code: starburst_map(   data, fn,   workers = 50,   oversubscribe = 1.2  # Launch 20% extra )

title: When to Use Cloud vs Local: A Practical Guide
text: 1. Benchmark locally first 2. Test small batch 3. Estimate full cost 4. Run full job acceptable 5. Compare optimize
code:
# Time your workload start <- Sys.time() results <- lapply(data, your_function) local_time <- difftime(Sys.time(), start, units = "secs")  cat(sprintf("Sequential: %.1f minutes
", local_time/60)) cat(sprintf("Parallel (%d cores): ~%.1f minutes
",             parallel::detectCores(),             local_time / parallel::detectCores() / 60)) # Try 10% of data first test_data <- data[1:ceiling(length(data)/10)] test_time <- starburst_map(test_data, your_function, workers = 10) # Extrapolate estimated_time <- test_time * 10 estimated_cost <- 10 * 2 * 0.04048 * (estimated_time/3600) cat(sprintf("Estimated: %.1f min, $%.2f
",             estimated_time/60, estimated_cost))

title: Wave Queue Reference Semantics Fix
text: R uses pass--value semantics, meaning function modifies object parameter, changes don‚Äôt persist caller unless object returned reassigned. Fix:
code: add_to_queue <- function(task_id, plan) {   plan$wave_queue$pending <- append(plan$wave_queue$pending, task_id)   check_and_submit_wave(plan)   invisible(NULL)  # Plan modifications lost! }  # Usage: add_to_queue("task-1", plan) # plan$wave_queue$pending is still empty!

title: Detached Session Mode
text: Detached sessions allow start long-running computations AWS, safely close R session, reattach later check progress collect results.

title: Detached Session Mode
text: analyses take hours days: Start detach: Launch computation close laptop Reattach anytime: Check progress R session Fault tolerant: computations continue even local R crashes Cost efficient: Workers auto-scale idle

title: Detached Session Mode
code: library(starburst)  # Create a detached session session <- starburst_session(   workers = 10,   cpu = 4,   memory = "8GB" )  # Submit tasks task_ids <- lapply(1:100, function(i) {   session$submit(quote({     # Your long-running computation     result <- expensive_analysis(i)     result   })) })  # Save session ID for later session_id <- session$session_id print(session_id)  # "session-abc123..."

title: Detached Session Mode
code: # Check progress anytime status <- session$status() print(status) # Session Status: #   Total tasks:     100 #   Pending:         25 #   Running:         10 #   Completed:       60 #   Failed:          5 #   Progress:        60.0%

title: Detached Session Mode
code: # Collect completed results (non-blocking) results <- session$collect(wait = FALSE) length(results)  # 60 (only completed so far)  # Or wait for all to complete results <- session$collect(wait = TRUE, timeout = 3600) length(results)  # 100 (all tasks)

title: Detached Session Mode

code: # Run 10,000 simulations session <- starburst_session(workers = 50)  n_sims <- 10000 lapply(1:n_sims, function(i) {   session$submit(quote({     set.seed(i)     run_simulation()   })) })  # Check progress periodically repeat {   status <- session$status()   print(sprintf("Progress: %.1f%%", 100 * status$completed / status$total))    if (status$completed == n_sims) break   Sys.sleep(60) }  results <- session$collect()

title: Example: Parallel Bulk API Calls
text: Making hundreds thousands API calls common bottleneck data pipelines. example demonstrates parallelizing REST API calls fetch data multiple endpoints. Use Case: Data enrichment, web scraping, external data integration, geocoding Computational Pattern: /O-bound parallel processing rate limiting

title: Example: Parallel Bulk API Calls
text: need enrich dataset 1,000 companies external data REST API: - Company financial metrics - Stock prices - News sentiment - ESG scores API call takes 0.5-2 seconds due network latency. Sequential execution take 8-30 minutes.

title: Example: Parallel Bulk API Calls
code: library(starburst) library(httr) library(jsonlite)

title: Example: Parallel Bulk API Calls
text: Define function fetches data one company:
code: fetch_company_data <- function(ticker) {   # Add small delay to respect rate limits   Sys.sleep(runif(1, 0.1, 0.3))    # For demo purposes, we'll use a public API   # In practice, replace with your actual API endpoint   base_url <- "https://api.example.com/company"    tryCatch({     # Fetch company info     response <- httr::GET(       paste0(base_url, "/", ticker),       httr::timeout(10),       httr::add_headers(         "User-Agent" = "staRburst-example/1.0"       )     )      # Check for success     if (httr::status_code(response) == 200) {       data <- httr::content(response, "parsed")        # Extract relevant fields       list(         ticker = ticker,         success = TRUE,         company_name = data$name %||% NA,         market_cap = data$marketCap %||% NA,         pe_ratio = data$peRatio %||% NA,         revenue = data$revenue %||% NA,         employees = data$employees %||% NA,         sector = data$sector %||% NA,         timestamp = Sys.time()       )     } else {       # Handle API errors       list(         ticker = ticker,         success = FALSE,         error = paste("HTTP", httr::status_code(response)),         timestamp = Sys.time()       )     }   }, error = function(e) {     # Handle network errors     list(       ticker = ticker,       success = FALSE,       error = as.character(e),       timestamp = Sys.time()     )   }) }  # Helper: null-coalescing operator `%||%` <- function(x, y) if (is.null(x)) y else x

title: Example: Parallel Bulk API Calls
text: Since need real API testing, let‚Äôs create mock function simulates API behavior:
code: # Mock function that simulates API with realistic delays fetch_company_data_mock <- function(ticker) {   # Simulate network latency   Sys.sleep(runif(1, 0.2, 0.8))    # Simulate occasional failures (5% rate)   if (runif(1) < 0.05) {     return(list(       ticker = ticker,       success = FALSE,       error = "API timeout",       timestamp = Sys.time()     ))   }    # Generate mock data   list(     ticker = ticker,     success = TRUE,     company_name = paste("Company", ticker),     market_cap = round(rnorm(1, 50e9, 20e9), 0),     pe_ratio = round(rnorm(1, 25, 10), 2),     revenue = round(rnorm(1, 10e9, 5e9), 0),     employees = round(rnorm(1, 50000, 20000), 0),     sector = sample(c("Technology", "Healthcare", "Finance", "Energy"), 1),     timestamp = Sys.time()   ) }

title: Example: Parallel Bulk API Calls
text: Key Insights: - Excellent scaling /O-bound workloads - Cost remains minimal even 50 workers - Network latency dominates computation time - Automatic retries handle transient failures

title: Example: Parallel Bulk API Calls
text: working real APIs: Rate limit calculation: - API limit: 100 calls/minute - Workers: 10 - Max throughput: 1000 calls/minute (10 workers √ó 100 calls/min) - Adjust workers stay limit
code: # Add jitter to respect rate limits fetch_with_rate_limit <- function(ticker, rate_limit = 100) {   # Add delay based on rate limit (calls per minute)   delay <- 60 / rate_limit + runif(1, 0, 0.1)   Sys.sleep(delay)    fetch_company_data(ticker) }  # Use with staRburst results <- starburst_map(   tickers,   function(x) fetch_with_rate_limit(x, rate_limit = 100),   workers = 10  # Adjust workers based on API rate limit )

title: Example: Parallel Bulk API Calls
code: fetch_with_retry <- function(ticker, max_retries = 3) {   for (attempt in 1:max_retries) {     result <- fetch_company_data(ticker)      if (result$success) {       return(result)     }      # Exponential backoff     if (attempt < max_retries) {       Sys.sleep(2^attempt + runif(1, 0, 1))     }   }    # Return failure after all retries   result$error <- paste("Failed after", max_retries, "retries:", result$error)   return(result) }

title: Example: Bootstrap Confidence Intervals for A/B Testing
text: Bootstrap resampling powerful statistical technique estimating confidence intervals without assuming specific distribution. example demonstrates parallelizing bootstrap analysis /B test results. Use Case: /B testing, hypothesis testing, statistical inference, conversion rate analysis Computational Pattern: Embarrassingly parallel resampling aggregation

title: Example: Bootstrap Confidence Intervals for A/B Testing
text: ‚Äôve run /B test website two variants: - Variant (Control): 10,000 visitors, 850 conversions (8.5% conversion rate) - Variant B (Treatment): 10,000 visitors, 920 conversions (9.2% conversion rate) need : 1. Estimate confidence interval difference conversion rates 2. Calculate probability B better 3. Determine result statistically significant Traditional parametric tests assume normal distributions. Bootstrap resampling makes assumptions provides robust estimates.

title: Example: Bootstrap Confidence Intervals for A/B Testing
code: library(starburst)

title: Example: Bootstrap Confidence Intervals for A/B Testing
text: Create synthetic /B test data: Output:
code:
set.seed(42)  # Variant A (control) n_a <- 10000 conversions_a <- 850 variant_a <- c(rep(1, conversions_a), rep(0, n_a - conversions_a))  # Variant B (treatment) n_b <- 10000 conversions_b <- 920 variant_b <- c(rep(1, conversions_b), rep(0, n_b - conversions_b))  # Observed difference observed_diff <- mean(variant_b) - mean(variant_a) cat(sprintf("Observed conversion rates:
")) cat(sprintf("  Variant A: %.2f%%
", mean(variant_a) * 100)) cat(sprintf("  Variant B: %.2f%%
", mean(variant_b) * 100)) cat(sprintf("  Difference: %.2f%% (%.1f%% relative lift)
",             observed_diff * 100,             (observed_diff / mean(variant_a)) * 100)) Observed conversion rates:   Variant A: 8.50%   Variant B: 9.20%   Difference: 0.70% (8.2% relative lift)

title: Example: Bootstrap Confidence Intervals for A/B Testing
text: Define function performs one bootstrap iteration:
code: bootstrap_iteration <- function(iter, data_a, data_b) {   # Resample with replacement   n_a <- length(data_a)   n_b <- length(data_b)    sample_a <- sample(data_a, n_a, replace = TRUE)   sample_b <- sample(data_b, n_b, replace = TRUE)    # Calculate metrics   rate_a <- mean(sample_a)   rate_b <- mean(sample_b)   diff <- rate_b - rate_a   relative_lift <- diff / rate_a    list(     iteration = iter,     rate_a = rate_a,     rate_b = rate_b,     diff = diff,     relative_lift = relative_lift,     b_wins = diff > 0   ) }

title: Example: Bootstrap Confidence Intervals for A/B Testing
text: Run smaller bootstrap locally: Typical output:

n_bootstrap_local <- 1000  cat(sprintf("Running %d bootstrap iterations locally...
", n_bootstrap_local)) local_start <- Sys.time()  local_results <- lapply(   1:n_bootstrap_local,   bootstrap_iteration,   data_a = variant_a,   data_b = variant_b )  local_time <- as.numeric(difftime(Sys.time(), local_start, units = "secs")) cat(sprintf("‚úì Completed in %.2f seconds

", local_time)) Running 1000 bootstrap iterations locally... ‚úì Completed in 2.1 seconds

title: Example: Bootstrap Confidence Intervals for A/B Testing
text: Extract analyze bootstrap distribution: Typical output:
code:

Probability that B > A: %.1f%%

Relative lift: %.1f%%

",             quantile(relative_lifts, 0.025) * 100,             quantile(relative_lifts, 0.975) * 100)) === Bootstrap Results (10,000 iterations) ===  Observed difference: 0.70%  95% Confidence Interval: [0.21%, 1.19%] 99% Confidence Interval: [0.08%, 1.32%]  Probability that B > A: 99.7%  ‚úì Result is statistically significant at 95% confidence level   (95% CI does not include zero)  Relative lift: 8.2% 95% CI for relative lift: [2.5%, 14.0%]

title: Example: Bootstrap Confidence Intervals for A/B Testing
text: Key Insights: - Bootstrap highly parallelizable - Fast iterations still benefit cloud parallelization - Minimal cost even 10,000 iterations - Can easily scale 100,000+ iterations precision

title: Example: Bootstrap Confidence Intervals for A/B Testing
text: Bootstrap multiple metrics simultaneously:
code: bootstrap_all_metrics <- function(iter, data_a, data_b) {   n_a <- length(data_a)   n_b <- length(data_b)    sample_a <- sample(data_a, n_a, replace = TRUE)   sample_b <- sample(data_b, n_b, replace = TRUE)    # Multiple metrics   rate_a <- mean(sample_a)   rate_b <- mean(sample_b)   se_a <- sd(sample_a) / sqrt(n_a)   se_b <- sd(sample_b) / sqrt(n_b)    list(     diff_rate = rate_b - rate_a,     relative_lift = (rate_b - rate_a) / rate_a,     z_score = (rate_b - rate_a) / sqrt(se_a^2 + se_b^2),     effect_size = (rate_b - rate_a) / sqrt((var(sample_a) + var(sample_b)) / 2)   ) }  # Run multi-metric bootstrap multi_results <- starburst_map(   1:10000,   bootstrap_all_metrics,   data_a = variant_a,   data_b = variant_b,   workers = 25 )

title: Example: Parallel Feature Engineering
text: Feature engineering often involves computationally expensive transformations across large datasets. example demonstrates parallelizing feature calculation across data segments dramatically speed preprocessing pipelines. Use Case: Machine learning preprocessing, ETL pipelines, data enrichment, time-series feature extraction Computational Pattern: Data parallelism chunked processing aggregation

title: Example: Parallel Feature Engineering
text: dataset 100,000 customer transactions need compute multiple engineered features: - Rolling statistics (moving averages, standard deviations) - Lag features (previous N values) - Time-based features (day week, month, seasonality) - Aggregated customer metrics (lifetime value, purchase frequency) - Text-based features (sentiment scores, keyword extraction) - Categorical encodings (target encoding, frequency encoding) Computing features sequentially slow. Parallelizing customer ID allows independent processing.

title: Example: Parallel Feature Engineering
code: library(starburst) library(dplyr)

title: Example: Parallel Feature Engineering
text: Create synthetic transaction data: Output:
code: set.seed(123)  # Generate 100,000 transactions for 5,000 customers n_customers <- 5000 n_transactions <- 100000  transactions <- data.frame(   customer_id = sample(1:n_customers, n_transactions, replace = TRUE),   transaction_date = as.Date("2023-01-01") + sample(0:364, n_transactions, replace = TRUE),   amount = exp(rnorm(n_transactions, log(50), 0.8)),  # Log-normal distribution   category = sample(c("groceries", "electronics", "clothing", "restaurants", "other"),                    n_transactions, replace = TRUE, prob = c(0.4, 0.1, 0.2, 0.2, 0.1)),   payment_method = sample(c("credit", "debit", "cash"), n_transactions, replace = TRUE),   is_online = sample(c(TRUE, FALSE), n_transactions, replace = TRUE, prob = c(0.3, 0.7)) )  # Sort by customer and date transactions <- transactions[order(transactions$customer_id, transactions$transaction_date), ]  cat(sprintf("Dataset: %s transactions for %s customers\n",             format(nrow(transactions), big.mark = ","),             format(length(unique(transactions$customer_id)), big.mark = ","))) cat(sprintf("Date range: %s to %s\n",             min(transactions$transaction_date),             max(transactions$transaction_date))) Dataset: 100,000 transactions for 5,000 customers Date range: 2023-01-01 to 2023-12-31

title: Example: Parallel Feature Engineering
text: Define function computes features set customers:
code: engineer_features <- function(customer_ids, transactions_data) {   # Filter to specified customers   customer_data <- transactions_data[transactions_data$customer_id %in% customer_ids, ]    if (nrow(customer_data) == 0) {     return(NULL)   }    # Sort by customer and date   customer_data <- customer_data[order(customer_data$customer_id,                                       customer_data$transaction_date), ]    # Compute features for each customer   features_list <- lapply(customer_ids, function(cid) {     cust_txn <- customer_data[customer_data$customer_id == cid, ]      if (nrow(cust_txn) == 0) {       return(NULL)     }      # Basic statistics     total_transactions <- nrow(cust_txn)     total_spend <- sum(cust_txn$amount)     avg_transaction <- mean(cust_txn$amount)      # Time-based features     first_purchase <- min(cust_txn$transaction_date)     last_purchase <- max(cust_txn$transaction_date)     days_active <- as.numeric(difftime(last_purchase, first_purchase, units = "days"))     purchase_frequency <- if (days_active > 0) total_transactions / days_active else 0      # Rolling statistics (last 30 days)     recent_cutoff <- last_purchase - 30     recent_txn <- cust_txn[cust_txn$transaction_date > recent_cutoff, ]     recent_spend <- if (nrow(recent_txn) > 0) sum(recent_txn$amount) else 0     recent_count <- nrow(recent_txn)      # Category preferences     category_counts <- table(cust_txn$category)     favorite_category <- names(category_counts)[which.max(category_counts)]     category_diversity <- length(unique(cust_txn$category))      # Payment behavior     online_pct <- mean(cust_txn$is_online) * 100     credit_pct <- mean(cust_txn$payment_method == "credit") * 100      # Volatility metrics     amount_sd <- sd(cust_txn$amount)     amount_cv <- amount_sd / avg_transaction  # Coefficient of variation      # Time patterns     weekday <- as.POSIXlt(cust_txn$transaction_date)$wday     weekend_pct <- mean(weekday %in% c(0, 6)) * 100      # RFM features (Recency, Frequency, Monetary)     recency <- as.numeric(difftime(as.Date("2024-01-01"), last_purchase, units = "days"))      data.frame(       customer_id = cid,       total_transactions = total_transactions,       total_spend = total_spend,       avg_transaction = avg_transaction,       days_active = days_active,       purchase_frequency = purchase_frequency,       recent_spend_30d = recent_spend,       recent_count_30d = recent_count,       favorite_category = favorite_category,       category_diversity = category_diversity,       online_pct = online_pct,       credit_pct = credit_pct,       amount_sd = amount_sd,       amount_cv = amount_cv,       weekend_pct = weekend_pct,       recency_days = recency,       stringsAsFactors = FALSE     )   })    # Combine results   do.call(rbind, features_list[!sapply(features_list, is.null)]) }

title: Example: Parallel Feature Engineering
text: Test feature engineering locally subset: Typical output: 5,000 customers locally: ~38 seconds
code:
# Process 500 customers locally set.seed(456) sample_customers <- sample(unique(transactions$customer_id), 500)  cat(sprintf("Processing features for %d customers locally...
", length(sample_customers))) local_start <- Sys.time()  local_features <- engineer_features(sample_customers, transactions)  local_time <- as.numeric(difftime(Sys.time(), local_start, units = "secs"))  cat(sprintf("‚úì Completed in %.2f seconds
", local_time)) cat(sprintf("  Generated %d features per customer
", ncol(local_features) - 1)) cat(sprintf("  Estimated time for all %s customers: %.1f minutes
",             format(n_customers, big.mark = ","),             local_time * (n_customers / 500) / 60)) Processing features for 500 customers locally... ‚úì Completed in 3.8 seconds   Generated 15 features per customer   Estimated time for all 5,000 customers: 38.0 seconds

title: Example: Parallel Feature Engineering
text: Process customers parallel AWS: Typical output:
code:
# Split customers into chunks all_customers <- unique(transactions$customer_id) n_workers <- 20  cat(sprintf("Processing features for %s customers on %d workers...
",             format(length(all_customers), big.mark = ","),             n_workers))  # Create chunks of customer IDs chunk_size <- ceiling(length(all_customers) / n_workers) customer_chunks <- split(all_customers,                         ceiling(seq_along(all_customers) / chunk_size))  cloud_start <- Sys.time()  # Process chunks in parallel results <- starburst_map(   customer_chunks,   engineer_features,   transactions_data = transactions,   workers = n_workers,   cpu = 2,   memory = "4GB" )  cloud_time <- as.numeric(difftime(Sys.time(), cloud_start, units = "secs"))  cat(sprintf("
‚úì Completed in %.1f seconds
", cloud_time))  # Combine results features <- do.call(rbind, results) üöÄ Starting starburst cluster with 20 workers üí∞ Estimated cost: ~$1.60/hour üìä Processing 20 items with 20 workers üì¶ Created 20 chunks (avg 250 customers per chunk) üöÄ Submitting tasks... ‚úì Submitted 20 tasks ‚è≥ Progress: 20/20 tasks (6.2 seconds elapsed)  ‚úì Completed in 6.2 seconds üí∞ Actual cost: $0.003

text: Key Insights: - Excellent parallelization efficiency (6x speedup) - Minimal cost significant time savings - Scales well larger datasets (100K+ customers) - Can process 100 customers/second 20 workers

title: Example: Parallel Feature Engineering
text: Extend feature function machine learning:
code: engineer_ml_features <- function(customer_ids, transactions_data) {   base_features <- engineer_features(customer_ids, transactions_data)    if (is.null(base_features)) {     return(NULL)   }    # Add derived features for ML   base_features$clv_estimate <- base_features$avg_transaction *                                  base_features$purchase_frequency * 365   base_features$engagement_score <- scale(base_features$total_transactions) +                                     scale(base_features$category_diversity)   base_features$recency_score <- -scale(base_features$recency_days)   base_features$is_high_value <- base_features$total_spend >                                   median(base_features$total_spend)   base_features$purchase_momentum <- base_features$recent_count_30d /                                      (base_features$total_transactions + 1)    base_features }  # Process with enhanced features ml_results <- starburst_map(   customer_chunks,   engineer_ml_features,   transactions_data = transactions,   workers = 20,   cpu = 2,   memory = "4GB" )  ml_features <- do.call(rbind, ml_results)

title: Example: Parallel Geospatial Analysis
text: Geospatial analysis often involves computationally expensive operations like distance calculations, spatial joins, geometric operations across large datasets. example demonstrates parallelizing spatial analysis across geographic regions. Use Case: Store location optimization, delivery route planning, spatial market analysis, environmental modeling Computational Pattern: Spatial data parallelism region-based chunking

title: Example: Parallel Geospatial Analysis
text: need analyze 100 retail locations across 20 metropolitan areas : - Calculate distances competitors - Identify optimal delivery zones - Compute demographic coverage - Analyze spatial clustering - Generate market penetration metrics region can analyzed independently, making ideal parallel processing.

title: Example: Parallel Geospatial Analysis
code: library(starburst)

title: Example: Parallel Geospatial Analysis
text: Create synthetic geospatial data: Output:
code:
set.seed(789)  # Define 20 metropolitan regions (simplified coordinates) regions <- data.frame(   region_id = 1:20,   region_name = c("New York", "Los Angeles", "Chicago", "Houston", "Phoenix",                  "Philadelphia", "San Antonio", "San Diego", "Dallas", "San Jose",                  "Austin", "Jacksonville", "Fort Worth", "Columbus", "Charlotte",                  "San Francisco", "Indianapolis", "Seattle", "Denver", "Boston"),   center_lat = c(40.71, 34.05, 41.88, 29.76, 33.45,                 39.95, 29.42, 32.72, 32.78, 37.34,                 30.27, 30.33, 32.75, 39.96, 35.23,                 37.77, 39.77, 47.61, 39.74, 42.36),   center_lon = c(-74.01, -118.24, -87.63, -95.37, -112.07,                 -75.17, -98.49, -117.16, -96.80, -121.89,                 -97.74, -81.66, -97.33, -83.00, -80.84,                 -122.42, -86.16, -122.33, -104.99, -71.06),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  # Generate store locations (5 per region) stores <- do.call(rbind, lapply(1:nrow(regions), function(i) {   n_stores <- 5   # Add random offset to region center   data.frame(     store_id = (i - 1) * n_stores + 1:n_stores,     region_id = regions$region_id[i],     region_name = regions$region_name[i],     latitude = regions$center_lat[i] + rnorm(n_stores, 0, 0.1),     longitude = regions$center_lon[i] + rnorm(n_stores, 0, 0.1),     annual_revenue = rlnorm(n_stores, log(1000000), 0.5),     stringsAsFactors = FALSE   ) }))  # Generate competitor locations (10 per region) competitors <- do.call(rbind, lapply(1:nrow(regions), function(i) {   n_competitors <- 10   data.frame(     competitor_id = (i - 1) * n_competitors + 1:n_competitors,     region_id = regions$region_id[i],     latitude = regions$center_lat[i] + rnorm(n_competitors, 0, 0.15),     longitude = regions$center_lon[i] + rnorm(n_competitors, 0, 0.15),     stringsAsFactors = FALSE   ) }))  # Generate customer points (1000 per region) customers <- do.call(rbind, lapply(1:nrow(regions), function(i) {   n_customers <- 1000   data.frame(     customer_id = (i - 1) * n_customers + 1:n_customers,     region_id = regions$region_id[i],     latitude = regions$center_lat[i] + rnorm(n_customers, 0, 0.2),     longitude = regions$center_lon[i] + rnorm(n_customers, 0, 0.2),     annual_spend = rlnorm(n_customers, log(500), 0.8),     stringsAsFactors = FALSE   ) }))  cat(sprintf("Dataset created:
")) cat(sprintf("  %d stores across %d regions
", nrow(stores), nrow(regions))) cat(sprintf("  %s competitors
", format(nrow(competitors), big.mark = ","))) cat(sprintf("  %s customers
", format(nrow(customers), big.mark = ","))) Dataset created:   100 stores across 20 regions   200 competitors   20,000 customers

title: Example: Parallel Geospatial Analysis
text: Define function performs spatial analysis region:
code: # Haversine distance function (in km) haversine_distance <- function(lat1, lon1, lat2, lon2) {   R <- 6371  # Earth's radius in km    lat1_rad <- lat1 * pi / 180   lat2_rad <- lat2 * pi / 180   delta_lat <- (lat2 - lat1) * pi / 180   delta_lon <- (lon2 - lon1) * pi / 180    a <- sin(delta_lat/2)^2 +        cos(lat1_rad) * cos(lat2_rad) * sin(delta_lon/2)^2   c <- 2 * atan2(sqrt(a), sqrt(1-a))    R * c }  analyze_region <- function(region_id, stores_data, competitors_data,                           customers_data) {   # Filter data for this region   region_stores <- stores_data[stores_data$region_id == region_id, ]   region_competitors <- competitors_data[competitors_data$region_id == region_id, ]   region_customers <- customers_data[customers_data$region_id == region_id, ]    if (nrow(region_stores) == 0) {     return(NULL)   }    # Analyze each store   store_metrics <- lapply(1:nrow(region_stores), function(i) {     store <- region_stores[i, ]      # Distance to nearest competitor     competitor_distances <- sapply(1:nrow(region_competitors), function(j) {       haversine_distance(         store$latitude, store$longitude,         region_competitors$latitude[j], region_competitors$longitude[j]       )     })     nearest_competitor_km <- min(competitor_distances)     avg_competitor_distance <- mean(competitor_distances)     competitors_within_5km <- sum(competitor_distances <= 5)      # Customer coverage analysis     customer_distances <- sapply(1:nrow(region_customers), function(j) {       haversine_distance(         store$latitude, store$longitude,         region_customers$latitude[j], region_customers$longitude[j]       )     })      # Customers within radius     customers_1km <- sum(customer_distances <= 1)     customers_3km <- sum(customer_distances <= 3)     customers_5km <- sum(customer_distances <= 5)     customers_10km <- sum(customer_distances <= 10)      # Market potential (customers within 5km)     nearby_customers <- region_customers[customer_distances <= 5, ]     market_potential <- if (nrow(nearby_customers) > 0) {       sum(nearby_customers$annual_spend)     } else {       0     }      # Average distance to customers     avg_customer_distance <- mean(customer_distances)     median_customer_distance <- median(customer_distances)      # Spatial density (customers per km¬≤ within 10km radius)     area_10km <- pi * 10^2  # ~314 km¬≤     customer_density <- customers_10km / area_10km      # Competitive intensity score (0-1, higher = more competitive)     competitive_intensity <- min(1, competitors_within_5km / 10)      data.frame(       store_id = store$store_id,       region_id = region_id,       region_name = store$region_name,       annual_revenue = store$annual_revenue,       nearest_competitor_km = nearest_competitor_km,       avg_competitor_distance = avg_competitor_distance,       competitors_within_5km = competitors_within_5km,       customers_1km = customers_1km,       customers_3km = customers_3km,       customers_5km = customers_5km,       customers_10km = customers_10km,       market_potential = market_potential,       avg_customer_distance = avg_customer_distance,       median_customer_distance = median_customer_distance,       customer_density = customer_density,       competitive_intensity = competitive_intensity,       stringsAsFactors = FALSE     )   })    do.call(rbind, store_metrics) }

title: Example: Parallel Geospatial Analysis

", length(test_regions))) local_start <- Sys.time()  local_results <- lapply(test_regions, analyze_region,                        stores_data = stores,                        competitors_data = competitors,                        customers_data = customers) local_metrics <- do.call(rbind, local_results)  local_time <- as.numeric(difftime(Sys.time(), local_start, units = "secs"))  cat(sprintf("‚úì Completed in %.2f seconds

",             sum(spatial_metrics$competitors_within_5km >= 5),             mean(spatial_metrics$competitors_within_5km >= 5) * 100))  # Customer coverage cat("=== Customer Coverage Analysis ===
") cat(sprintf("Average customers within 5km: %.0f
",             mean(spatial_metrics$customers_5km))) cat(sprintf("Average market potential (5km radius): $%.0f

",             mean(spatial_metrics$customer_density))) cat(sprintf("Median distance to customers: %.2f km

",             mean(spatial_metrics$median_customer_distance)))  # Store performance correlation cat("=== Performance Insights ===
") correlation <- cor(spatial_metrics$annual_revenue,                    spatial_metrics$market_potential) cat(sprintf("Correlation (revenue vs market potential): %.3f
", correlation))  # Identify opportunity stores opportunity_stores <- spatial_metrics[   spatial_metrics$market_potential > median(spatial_metrics$market_potential) &   spatial_metrics$competitors_within_5km < median(spatial_metrics$competitors_within_5km), ] cat(sprintf("
High opportunity stores (low competition, high potential): %d
",             nrow(opportunity_stores))) if (nrow(opportunity_stores) > 0) {   cat(sprintf("  Average market potential: $%.0f
",               mean(opportunity_stores$market_potential)))   cat(sprintf("  Average competitors nearby: %.1f
",               mean(opportunity_stores$competitors_within_5km))) }  # Identify challenged stores challenged_stores <- spatial_metrics[   spatial_metrics$competitive_intensity > 0.7 &   spatial_metrics$market_potential < median(spatial_metrics$market_potential), ] cat(sprintf("
Challenged stores (high competition, low potential): %d
",             nrow(challenged_stores))) if (nrow(challenged_stores) > 0) {   cat(sprintf("  Average market potential: $%.0f

",               mean(challenged_stores$competitors_within_5km))) }  # Top regions by market potential cat("
=== Top 5 Regions by Market Potential ===

", i,               region_summary$region_name[i],               region_summary$market_potential[i])) } === Geospatial Analysis Results ===  Total stores analyzed: 100 Regions covered: 20  === Competition Analysis === Average distance to nearest competitor: 2.34 km Median distance to nearest competitor: 2.18 km Average competitors within 5km: 6.2 Stores with high competition (5+ competitors within 5km): 58 (58.0%)  === Customer Coverage Analysis === Average customers within 5km: 512 Average market potential (5km radius): $256,345 Average customer density: 3.2 customers/km¬≤ Median distance to customers: 4.12 km  === Performance Insights === Correlation (revenue vs market potential): 0.423  High opportunity stores (low competition, high potential): 12   Average market potential: $342,567   Average competitors nearby: 3.2  Challenged stores (high competition, low potential): 8   Average market potential: $178,234   Average competitors nearby: 8.4  === Top 5 Regions by Market Potential === 1. title: Example: Parallel Geospatial Analysis
text: Extend compute optimal delivery zones:
code: optimize_delivery_zones <- function(region_id, stores_data, customers_data) {   region_stores <- stores_data[stores_data$region_id == region_id, ]   region_customers <- customers_data[customers_data$region_id == region_id, ]    # Assign each customer to nearest store   customer_assignments <- lapply(1:nrow(region_customers), function(i) {     customer <- region_customers[i, ]      distances <- sapply(1:nrow(region_stores), function(j) {       haversine_distance(         customer$latitude, customer$longitude,         region_stores$latitude[j], region_stores$longitude[j]       )     })      nearest_store <- which.min(distances)      list(       customer_id = customer$customer_id,       assigned_store = region_stores$store_id[nearest_store],       distance_km = distances[nearest_store],       annual_spend = customer$annual_spend     )   })    # Aggregate by store   assignments_df <- do.call(rbind, lapply(customer_assignments, as.data.frame))    store_zones <- aggregate(     cbind(customer_count = customer_id,           total_revenue = annual_spend,           avg_distance = distance_km) ~ assigned_store,     data = assignments_df,     FUN = function(x) if (is.numeric(x)) mean(x) else length(x)   )    store_zones }  # Run optimization zone_results <- starburst_map(   regions$region_id,   optimize_delivery_zones,   stores_data = stores,   customers_data = customers,   workers = 20 )
