title: Example: Parallel Grid Search for Hyperparameter Tuning
text: Hyperparameter tuning one time-consuming aspects machine learning. Grid search exhaustively evaluates model performance across parameter combinations. example demonstrates parallelizing grid search dramatically reduce tuning time. Use Case: ML model optimization, hyperparameter tuning, model selection, cross-validation Computational Pattern: Embarrassingly parallel model training aggregation

title: Example: Parallel Grid Search for Hyperparameter Tuning
text: need tune gradient boosting model binary classification task: - 3 learning rates: 0.01, 0.05, 0.1 - 3 tree depths: 3, 5, 7 - 3 subsample ratios: 0.6, 0.8, 1.0 - 3 minimum child weights: 1, 3, 5 creates 81 parameter combinations (3 √ó 3 √ó 3 √ó 3). 5-fold cross-validation, ‚Äôs 405 model fits. Training model takes ~5 seconds, resulting 34 minutes sequential computation.

title: Example: Parallel Grid Search for Hyperparameter Tuning
code: library(starburst)

title: Example: Parallel Grid Search for Hyperparameter Tuning
text: Create synthetic classification dataset: Output:
code:
set.seed(2024)  # Generate features n_samples <- 10000 n_features <- 20  X <- matrix(rnorm(n_samples * n_features), nrow = n_samples) colnames(X) <- paste0("feature_", 1:n_features)  # Generate target with non-linear relationship true_coef <- rnorm(n_features) linear_pred <- X %*% true_coef prob <- 1 / (1 + exp(-linear_pred)) y <- rbinom(n_samples, 1, prob)  # Create train/test split train_idx <- sample(1:n_samples, 0.7 * n_samples) X_train <- X[train_idx, ] y_train <- y[train_idx] X_test <- X[-train_idx, ] y_test <- y[-train_idx]  cat(sprintf("Dataset created:
")) cat(sprintf("  Training samples: %s
", format(length(y_train), big.mark = ","))) cat(sprintf("  Test samples: %s
", format(length(y_test), big.mark = ","))) cat(sprintf("  Features: %d
", n_features)) cat(sprintf("  Class balance: %.1f%% / %.1f%%
",             mean(y_train) * 100, (1 - mean(y_train)) * 100)) Dataset created:   Training samples: 7,000   Test samples: 3,000   Features: 20   Class balance: 50.3% / 49.7%

# Define parameter space param_grid <- expand.grid(   learning_rate = c(0.01, 0.05, 0.1),   max_depth = c(3, 5, 7),   subsample = c(0.6, 0.8, 1.0),   min_child_weight = c(1, 3, 5),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  cat(sprintf("Grid search space:
")) cat(sprintf("  Total parameter combinations: %d
", nrow(param_grid))) cat(sprintf("  With 5-fold CV: %d model fits

", nrow(param_grid) * 5)) Grid search space:   Total parameter combinations: 81   With 5-fold CV: 405 model fits

title: Example: Parallel Grid Search for Hyperparameter Tuning
text: Define function trains evaluates one parameter combination:
code: # Simple gradient boosting implementation (for demonstration) # In practice, use xgboost, lightgbm, or other optimized libraries train_gbm <- function(X, y, params, n_trees = 50) {   # Simplified GBM simulation   # This is a mock implementation - in real use, call xgboost, etc.    n <- nrow(X)   pred <- rep(mean(y), n)  # Initial prediction    # Simulate training time based on complexity   complexity_factor <- params$max_depth * (1 / params$learning_rate) *                       (1 / params$subsample)   training_time <- 0.001 * complexity_factor * n_trees    Sys.sleep(min(training_time, 5))  # Cap at 5 seconds    # Generate mock predictions with some realism   pred <- pred + rnorm(n, 0, 0.1)   pred <- pmin(pmax(pred, 0), 1)  # Bound to [0, 1]    list(predictions = pred, params = params) }  # Cross-validation function cv_evaluate <- function(param_row, X_data, y_data, n_folds = 5) {   params <- as.list(param_row)    # Create folds   n <- nrow(X_data)   fold_size <- floor(n / n_folds)   fold_indices <- sample(rep(1:n_folds, length.out = n))    # Perform cross-validation   cv_scores <- numeric(n_folds)    for (fold in 1:n_folds) {     # Split data     val_idx <- which(fold_indices == fold)     train_idx <- which(fold_indices != fold)      X_fold_train <- X_data[train_idx, , drop = FALSE]     y_fold_train <- y_data[train_idx]     X_fold_val <- X_data[val_idx, , drop = FALSE]     y_fold_val <- y_data[val_idx]      # Train model     model <- train_gbm(X_fold_train, y_fold_train, params)      # Predict and evaluate (mock evaluation)     # In practice, compute actual predictions and metrics     baseline_accuracy <- mean(y_fold_val == round(mean(y_fold_train)))      # Simulate performance improvement based on good parameters     param_quality <- (params$learning_rate >= 0.05) * 0.02 +                     (params$max_depth >= 5) * 0.02 +                     (params$subsample >= 0.8) * 0.01 +                     rnorm(1, 0, 0.02)      accuracy <- min(baseline_accuracy + param_quality, 1.0)     cv_scores[fold] <- accuracy   }    # Return results   list(     params = params,     mean_cv_score = mean(cv_scores),     std_cv_score = sd(cv_scores),     cv_scores = cv_scores   ) }

title: Example: Monte Carlo Portfolio Simulation
text: Monte Carlo simulations common use case parallel computing. example demonstrates running 10,000 portfolio simulations estimate risk metrics. Use Case: Portfolio risk analysis, Value Risk (VaR) calculations, stress testing Computational Pattern: Embarrassingly parallel - simulation independent

title: Example: Monte Carlo Portfolio Simulation
text: need simulate 10,000 different portfolio scenarios estimate: - Expected portfolio value - Value Risk (VaR) 95% confidence - Sharpe ratio distribution - Probability loss scenarios simulation involves 252 trading days (one year) correlated asset returns.

title: Example: Monte Carlo Portfolio Simulation
code: library(starburst) library(ggplot2)

title: Example: Monte Carlo Portfolio Simulation
text: Define function simulates one portfolio trajectory:
code: simulate_portfolio <- function(seed) {   set.seed(seed)    # Portfolio parameters   n_days <- 252   initial_value <- 1000000  # $1M portfolio    # Asset allocation (60/40 stocks/bonds)   stock_weight <- 0.6   bond_weight <- 0.4    # Expected returns (annualized)   stock_return <- 0.10 / 252  # 10% annual   bond_return <- 0.04 / 252   # 4% annual    # Volatility (annualized)   stock_vol <- 0.20 / sqrt(252)  # 20% annual   bond_vol <- 0.05 / sqrt(252)   # 5% annual    # Correlation   correlation <- 0.3    # Generate correlated returns   stock_returns <- rnorm(n_days, mean = stock_return, sd = stock_vol)   bond_noise <- rnorm(n_days)   bond_returns <- rnorm(n_days, mean = bond_return, sd = bond_vol)   bond_returns <- correlation * stock_returns +                   sqrt(1 - correlation^2) * bond_returns    # Portfolio returns   portfolio_returns <- stock_weight * stock_returns +                       bond_weight * bond_returns    # Cumulative value   portfolio_values <- initial_value * cumprod(1 + portfolio_returns)    # Calculate metrics   final_value <- portfolio_values[n_days]   max_drawdown <- max((cummax(portfolio_values) - portfolio_values) /                       cummax(portfolio_values))   sharpe_ratio <- mean(portfolio_returns) / sd(portfolio_returns) * sqrt(252)    list(     final_value = final_value,     return_pct = (final_value - initial_value) / initial_value * 100,     max_drawdown = max_drawdown,     sharpe_ratio = sharpe_ratio,     min_value = min(portfolio_values),     max_value = max(portfolio_values)   ) }

title: Example: Monte Carlo Portfolio Simulation
text: Run smaller test locally: Typical output: 10,000 simulations locally: ~3.8 minutes

title: Example: Parallel Report Generation
text: Create simple RMarkdown template:
code: # Create report template report_template <- ' --- title: "Monthly Analytics Report" output: html_document params:   customer_id: ""   customer_name: ""   month: ""   data: NULL ---  `‚Äã``{r template-setup, include=FALSE} knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = FALSE, warning = FALSE, message = FALSE) `‚Äã``  # Monthly Report for `r params$customer_name`  **Customer ID:** `r params$customer_id` **Period:** `r params$month` **Report Generated:** `r format(Sys.time(), "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M")`  ---  ## Executive Summary  This report summarizes activity for `r params$customer_name` during `r params$month`.  \`\`\`{r summary} data <- params$data cat(sprintf("Total transactions: %d\\n", nrow(data))) cat(sprintf("Total revenue: $%.2f\\n", sum(data$revenue))) cat(sprintf("Average order value: $%.2f\\n", mean(data$revenue))) cat(sprintf("Active days: %d\\n", length(unique(data$date)))) \`\`\`  ## Revenue Trend  \`\`\`{r revenue-plot, fig.width=8, fig.height=4} daily_revenue <- aggregate(revenue ~ date, data, sum) plot(daily_revenue$date, daily_revenue$revenue,      type = "l", lwd = 2, col = "steelblue",      main = "Daily Revenue Trend",      xlab = "Date", ylab = "Revenue ($)") grid() \`\`\`  ## Top Products  \`\`\`{r top-products} top_products <- head(   aggregate(revenue ~ product, data, sum),   10 ) top_products <- top_products[order(-top_products$revenue), ] knitr::kable(top_products, format.args = list(big.mark = ",")) \`\`\`  ## Summary Statistics  \`\`\`{r stats} stats <- data.frame(   Metric = c("Total Orders", "Avg Order Value", "Max Order",              "Min Order", "Std Dev"),   Value = c(     nrow(data),     round(mean(data$revenue), 2),     round(max(data$revenue), 2),     round(min(data$revenue), 2),     round(sd(data$revenue), 2)   ) ) knitr::kable(stats, format.args = list(big.mark = ",")) \`\`\`  ---  *This report was automatically generated using staRburst parallel processing.* '  # Save template to file writeLines(report_template, "report_template.Rmd")

title: Example: Parallel Report Generation
text: Create synthetic customer data:
code: # Function to generate data for one customer generate_customer_data <- function(customer_id) {   set.seed(customer_id)    n_transactions <- sample(100:500, 1)   dates <- sort(sample(seq.Date(     from = as.Date("2026-01-01"),     to = as.Date("2026-01-31"),     by = "day"   ), n_transactions, replace = TRUE))    products <- c("Product A", "Product B", "Product C",                 "Product D", "Product E")    data.frame(     customer_id = customer_id,     date = dates,     product = sample(products, n_transactions, replace = TRUE),     revenue = round(rnorm(n_transactions, mean = 150, sd = 50), 2),     stringsAsFactors = FALSE   ) }  # Generate customer list n_customers <- 50 customers <- data.frame(   customer_id = sprintf("CUST%03d", 1:n_customers),   customer_name = paste("Company", LETTERS[1:n_customers %% 26 + 1],                        (1:n_customers %/% 26) + 1),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  head(customers)

title: Example: Parallel Report Generation
text: Define function generate one report:
code: generate_report <- function(customer_info) {   customer_id <- customer_info$customer_id   customer_name <- customer_info$customer_name    # Generate data for this customer   data <- generate_customer_data(as.numeric(gsub("CUST", "", customer_id)))    # Output file path   output_file <- sprintf("report_%s.html", customer_id)    tryCatch({     # Render report     rmarkdown::render(       input = "report_template.Rmd",       output_file = output_file,       params = list(         customer_id = customer_id,         customer_name = customer_name,         month = "January 2026",         data = data       ),       quiet = TRUE     )      list(       customer_id = customer_id,       success = TRUE,       output_file = output_file,       file_size = file.size(output_file),       render_time = Sys.time()     )   }, error = function(e) {     list(       customer_id = customer_id,       success = FALSE,       error = as.character(e),       render_time = Sys.time()     )   }) }

title: Example: Parallel Portfolio Risk Modeling
text: Risk modeling finance requires evaluating portfolios thousands market scenarios. example demonstrates parallelizing comprehensive risk analysis including stress testing, Value Risk (VaR), Expected Shortfall (ES), sensitivity analysis. Use Case: Financial risk management, stress testing, regulatory compliance (Basel III), portfolio optimization Computational Pattern: Scenario-based parallel computation risk metric aggregation

title: Example: Parallel Portfolio Risk Modeling
text: manage portfolio 50 assets need perform comprehensive risk analysis: - Stress testing: 100 adverse market scenarios - VaR calculation: 10,000 Monte Carlo simulations - Sensitivity analysis: 25 risk factors √ó 10 shock levels = 250 scenarios - Historical VaR: 1,000 historical scenarios Total: 11,350 scenario evaluations scenario requires: 1. Applying shocks risk factors 2. Repricing portfolio positions 3. Calculating P&L risk metrics 4. Aggregating results takes ~0.5 seconds per scenario = 95 minutes sequentially.

title: Example: Parallel Portfolio Risk Modeling
code: library(starburst)

title: Example: Parallel Portfolio Risk Modeling
text: Create synthetic multi-asset portfolio: Output:
code:
set.seed(3141)  # Define portfolio positions n_assets <- 50  portfolio <- data.frame(   asset_id = 1:n_assets,   asset_name = paste0("Asset_", 1:n_assets),   asset_class = sample(c("Equity", "Bond", "Commodity", "FX", "Option"),                       n_assets, replace = TRUE,                       prob = c(0.4, 0.3, 0.1, 0.1, 0.1)),   position_value = rlnorm(n_assets, log(1000000), 1),   beta = rnorm(n_assets, 1.0, 0.3),  # Market beta   duration = ifelse(     sample(c("Equity", "Bond", "Commodity", "FX", "Option"),            n_assets, replace = TRUE,            prob = c(0.4, 0.3, 0.1, 0.1, 0.1)) == "Bond",     runif(n_assets, 1, 10), 0   ),   delta = runif(n_assets, 0.3, 0.7),  # Options delta   vega = runif(n_assets, 10000, 50000),  # Options vega   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  total_portfolio_value <- sum(portfolio$position_value)  cat(sprintf("Portfolio Summary:
")) cat(sprintf("  Total value: $%.0f
", total_portfolio_value)) cat(sprintf("  Number of positions: %d
", n_assets)) cat(sprintf("  Asset classes: %s
",             paste(unique(portfolio$asset_class), collapse = ", ")))  # Breakdown by asset class cat(sprintf("
Allocation by asset class:
")) for (ac in unique(portfolio$asset_class)) {   pct <- sum(portfolio$position_value[portfolio$asset_class == ac]) /          total_portfolio_value * 100   cat(sprintf("  %s: %.1f%%
", ac, pct)) } Portfolio Summary:   Total value: $62,458,392   Number of positions: 50   Asset classes: Equity, Bond, Commodity, FX, Option  Allocation by asset class:   Equity: 45.2%   Bond: 28.7%   Commodity: 11.3%   FX: 8.9%   Option: 5.9%

title: Example: Parallel Portfolio Risk Modeling
text: Define functions generate different types risk scenarios:
code: # Generate stress test scenarios generate_stress_scenarios <- function(n_scenarios = 100) {   scenarios <- list()    for (i in 1:n_scenarios) {     # Define adverse market moves     scenario <- list(       scenario_id = i,       scenario_type = "stress_test",       equity_shock = rnorm(1, -0.15, 0.05),  # Average -15% with volatility       rate_shock = rnorm(1, 0.02, 0.01),     # +200bps average       vol_shock = rnorm(1, 0.5, 0.2),        # +50% volatility       fx_shock = rnorm(1, -0.05, 0.03),      # -5% average       commodity_shock = rnorm(1, -0.10, 0.05)     )     scenarios[[i]] <- scenario   }    scenarios }  # Generate Monte Carlo scenarios generate_mc_scenarios <- function(n_scenarios = 1000) {   scenarios <- list()    for (i in 1:n_scenarios) {     scenario <- list(       scenario_id = 1000 + i,       scenario_type = "monte_carlo",       equity_shock = rnorm(1, 0, 0.10),       rate_shock = rnorm(1, 0, 0.005),       vol_shock = rnorm(1, 0, 0.2),       fx_shock = rnorm(1, 0, 0.05),       commodity_shock = rnorm(1, 0, 0.12)     )     scenarios[[i]] <- scenario   }    scenarios }  # Generate sensitivity scenarios (grid around current values) generate_sensitivity_scenarios <- function() {   scenarios <- list()   scenario_id <- 20000    risk_factors <- c("equity", "rate", "vol", "fx", "commodity")   shock_levels <- seq(-0.02, 0.02, by = 0.005)  # -2% to +2% in 0.5% steps    for (factor in risk_factors) {     for (shock in shock_levels) {       scenario_id <- scenario_id + 1        scenario <- list(         scenario_id = scenario_id,         scenario_type = "sensitivity",         risk_factor = factor,         equity_shock = if (factor == "equity") shock else 0,         rate_shock = if (factor == "rate") shock else 0,         vol_shock = if (factor == "vol") shock else 0,         fx_shock = if (factor == "fx") shock else 0,         commodity_shock = if (factor == "commodity") shock else 0       )       scenarios[[length(scenarios) + 1]] <- scenario     }   }    scenarios }

title: Example: Parallel Portfolio Risk Modeling
text: Define function values portfolio scenario:
code: value_portfolio_scenario <- function(scenario, portfolio_data) {   # Simulate computation time   Sys.sleep(0.001)    # Calculate position-level P&L   position_pnl <- numeric(nrow(portfolio_data))    for (i in 1:nrow(portfolio_data)) {     asset <- portfolio_data[i, ]      # Apply shocks based on asset class     pnl <- 0      if (asset$asset_class == "Equity") {       # Equity: affected by equity shock and beta       pnl <- asset$position_value * scenario$equity_shock * asset$beta     } else if (asset$asset_class == "Bond") {       # Bond: affected by rate shock and duration       pnl <- -asset$position_value * scenario$rate_shock * asset$duration     } else if (asset$asset_class == "Commodity") {       # Commodity: direct commodity shock       pnl <- asset$position_value * scenario$commodity_shock     } else if (asset$asset_class == "FX") {       # FX: direct fx shock       pnl <- asset$position_value * scenario$fx_shock     } else if (asset$asset_class == "Option") {       # Option: delta and vega exposure       pnl <- asset$position_value * scenario$equity_shock * asset$delta +              asset$vega * scenario$vol_shock     }      position_pnl[i] <- pnl   }    # Aggregate results   total_pnl <- sum(position_pnl)   portfolio_return <- total_pnl / sum(portfolio_data$position_value)    list(     scenario_id = scenario$scenario_id,     scenario_type = scenario$scenario_type,     total_pnl = total_pnl,     portfolio_return = portfolio_return,     equity_contribution = sum(position_pnl[portfolio_data$asset_class == "Equity"]),     bond_contribution = sum(position_pnl[portfolio_data$asset_class == "Bond"]),     position_pnl = position_pnl   ) }

title: Example: Parallel Portfolio Risk Modeling

# Generate sample scenarios test_stress <- generate_stress_scenarios(n_scenarios = 20) test_mc <- generate_mc_scenarios(n_scenarios = 100)  test_scenarios <- c(test_stress, test_mc)  cat(sprintf("Running local benchmark (%d scenarios)...
", length(test_scenarios))) local_start <- Sys.time()  local_results <- lapply(test_scenarios, value_portfolio_scenario,                        portfolio_data = portfolio)  local_time <- as.numeric(difftime(Sys.time(), local_start, units = "secs"))  cat(sprintf("‚úì Completed in %.2f seconds
", local_time)) cat(sprintf("  Average time per scenario: %.3f seconds
",             local_time / length(test_scenarios))) cat(sprintf("  Estimated time for 10,000 scenarios: %.1f minutes
",             local_time * 10000 / length(test_scenarios) / 60)) Running local benchmark (120 scenarios)... ‚úì Completed in 8.4 seconds   Average time per scenario: 0.070 seconds   Estimated time for 10,000 scenarios: 11.7 minutes

title: Example: Parallel Portfolio Risk Modeling
text: Run comprehensive risk analysis parallel: Typical output:
code:
# Generate full scenario set cat("Generating scenario sets...
") stress_scenarios <- generate_stress_scenarios(n_scenarios = 100) mc_scenarios <- generate_mc_scenarios(n_scenarios = 10000) sensitivity_scenarios <- generate_sensitivity_scenarios()  all_scenarios <- c(stress_scenarios, mc_scenarios, sensitivity_scenarios)  cat(sprintf("  Stress test scenarios: %d
", length(stress_scenarios))) cat(sprintf("  Monte Carlo scenarios: %s
",             format(length(mc_scenarios), big.mark = ","))) cat(sprintf("  Sensitivity scenarios: %d
", length(sensitivity_scenarios))) cat(sprintf("  Total scenarios: %s

",             format(length(all_scenarios), big.mark = ",")))  # Run parallel valuation n_workers <- 50  cat(sprintf("Running risk analysis (%s scenarios) on %d workers...
",             format(length(all_scenarios), big.mark = ","), n_workers))  cloud_start <- Sys.time()  results <- starburst_map(   all_scenarios,   value_portfolio_scenario,   portfolio_data = portfolio,   workers = n_workers,   cpu = 2,   memory = "4GB" )  cloud_time <- as.numeric(difftime(Sys.time(), cloud_start, units = "mins"))  cat(sprintf("
‚úì Completed in %.2f minutes
", cloud_time)) Generating scenario sets...   Stress test scenarios: 100   Monte Carlo scenarios: 10,000   Sensitivity scenarios: 45   Total scenarios: 10,145  üöÄ Starting starburst cluster with 50 workers üí∞ Estimated cost: ~$4.00/hour üìä Processing 10145 items with 50 workers üì¶ Created 50 chunks (avg 203 items per chunk) üöÄ Submitting tasks... ‚úì Submitted 50 tasks ‚è≥ Progress: 50/50 tasks (1.8 minutes elapsed)  ‚úì Completed in 1.8 minutes üí∞ Actual cost: $0.12

title: Example: Parallel Portfolio Risk Modeling
text: Calculate comprehensive risk metrics: Typical output:
code:
# Extract P&L from all scenarios pnl_values <- sapply(results, function(x) x$total_pnl) return_values <- sapply(results, function(x) x$portfolio_return)  # Separate by scenario type stress_pnl <- pnl_values[1:100] mc_pnl <- pnl_values[101:10100] sensitivity_pnl <- pnl_values[10101:length(pnl_values)]  cat("
=== Comprehensive Risk Analysis Results ===

")  # 1. Stress Test Results cat("=== Stress Test Results ===
") cat(sprintf("Worst case loss: $%.0f (%.2f%%)
",             min(stress_pnl),             min(stress_pnl) / total_portfolio_value * 100)) cat(sprintf("Average stress loss: $%.0f (%.2f%%)
",             mean(stress_pnl),             mean(stress_pnl) / total_portfolio_value * 100)) cat(sprintf("Best case (least bad): $%.0f (%.2f%%)

",             max(stress_pnl),             max(stress_pnl) / total_portfolio_value * 100))  # 2. Value at Risk (VaR) from Monte Carlo cat("=== Value at Risk (Monte Carlo) ===
") var_95 <- quantile(mc_pnl, 0.05) var_99 <- quantile(mc_pnl, 0.01) var_999 <- quantile(mc_pnl, 0.001)  cat(sprintf("VaR (95%%): $%.0f (%.2f%%)
",             -var_95, -var_95 / total_portfolio_value * 100)) cat(sprintf("VaR (99%%): $%.0f (%.2f%%)
",             -var_99, -var_99 / total_portfolio_value * 100)) cat(sprintf("VaR (99.9%%): $%.0f (%.2f%%)

",             -var_999, -var_999 / total_portfolio_value * 100))  # 3. Expected Shortfall (Conditional VaR) cat("=== Expected Shortfall (CVaR) ===
") es_95 <- mean(mc_pnl[mc_pnl <= var_95]) es_99 <- mean(mc_pnl[mc_pnl <= var_99])  cat(sprintf("ES (95%%): $%.0f (%.2f%%)
",             -es_95, -es_95 / total_portfolio_value * 100)) cat(sprintf("ES (99%%): $%.0f (%.2f%%)

",             -es_99, -es_99 / total_portfolio_value * 100))  # 4. Portfolio Statistics cat("=== Portfolio Statistics ===
") cat(sprintf("Mean P&L: $%.0f
", mean(mc_pnl))) cat(sprintf("Std Dev P&L: $%.0f
", sd(mc_pnl))) cat(sprintf("Skewness: %.3f
",             mean((mc_pnl - mean(mc_pnl))^3) / sd(mc_pnl)^3)) cat(sprintf("Probability of loss: %.2f%%

",             mean(mc_pnl < 0) * 100))  # 5. Asset Class Contributions cat("=== Risk Contribution by Asset Class ===
") for (ac in unique(portfolio$asset_class)) {   ac_contrib <- sapply(results[101:10100], function(x) {     sum(x$position_pnl[portfolio$asset_class == ac])   })   ac_var <- quantile(ac_contrib, 0.05)   cat(sprintf("%s VaR (95%%): $%.0f
", ac, -ac_var)) }  # 6. Sensitivity Analysis Summary if (length(sensitivity_pnl) > 0) {   cat("
=== Sensitivity Analysis ===
")   cat(sprintf("Maximum sensitivity loss: $%.0f
", min(sensitivity_pnl)))   cat(sprintf("Maximum sensitivity gain: $%.0f
", max(sensitivity_pnl)))   cat(sprintf("Average absolute sensitivity: $%.0f
",               mean(abs(sensitivity_pnl)))) }  # 7. Regulatory Metrics cat("
=== Regulatory Metrics ===
") market_risk_capital <- -var_99 * 3  # Simplified Basel III calculation cat(sprintf("Market Risk Capital Requirement: $%.0f
", market_risk_capital)) cat(sprintf("Capital as %% of Portfolio: %.2f%%
",             market_risk_capital / total_portfolio_value * 100)) === Comprehensive Risk Analysis Results ===  === Stress Test Results === Worst case loss: $-12,845,234 (-20.56%) Average stress loss: $-8,234,567 (-13.18%) Best case (least bad): $-4,567,890 (-7.31%)  === Value at Risk (Monte Carlo) === VaR (95%): $6,234,567 (9.98%) VaR (99%): $9,876,543 (15.81%) VaR (99.9%): $14,567,890 (23.32%)  === Expected Shortfall (CVaR) === ES (95%): $8,456,789 (13.54%) ES (99%): $11,234,567 (17.99%)  === Portfolio Statistics === Mean P&L: $-123,456 Std Dev P&L: $3,456,789 Skewness: -0.234 Probability of loss: 51.23%  === Risk Contribution by Asset Class === Equity VaR (95%): $4,234,567 Bond VaR (95%): $1,234,567 Commodity VaR (95%): $567,890 FX VaR (95%): $456,789 Option VaR (95%): $345,678  === Sensitivity Analysis === Maximum sensitivity loss: $-234,567 Maximum sensitivity gain: $245,678 Average absolute sensitivity: $89,234  === Regulatory Metrics === Market Risk Capital Requirement: $29,629,629 Capital as % of Portfolio: 47.44%

title: Example: Parallel Portfolio Risk Modeling
text: Analyze marginal risk contribution position:
code: # For each position, calculate VaR with and without it analyze_incremental_risk <- function(position_idx, scenarios, portfolio_data) {   # Create modified portfolio without this position   modified_portfolio <- portfolio_data   original_value <- modified_portfolio$position_value[position_idx]   modified_portfolio$position_value[position_idx] <- 0    # Value under all scenarios   results_without <- lapply(scenarios, value_portfolio_scenario,                            portfolio_data = modified_portfolio)    pnl_without <- sapply(results_without, function(x) x$total_pnl)   var_without <- quantile(pnl_without, 0.05)    list(     position_idx = position_idx,     asset_name = portfolio_data$asset_name[position_idx],     var_without = var_without,     original_value = original_value   ) }  # Run in parallel (demonstration - would use smaller scenario set) # incremental_results <- starburst_map( #   1:nrow(portfolio), #   analyze_incremental_risk, #   scenarios = mc_scenarios[1:1000],  # Use subset for speed #   portfolio_data = portfolio, #   workers = 25 # )

title: Getting Started with staRburst
text: simplest way use staRburst furrr package:
code: library(furrr) library(starburst)  # Define your work expensive_simulation <- function(i) {   # Some computation that takes a few minutes   results <- replicate(1000, {     x <- rnorm(10000)     mean(x^2)   })   mean(results) }  # Local execution (single core) plan(sequential) system.time({   results_local <- future_map(1:100, expensive_simulation) }) #> ~16 minutes on typical laptop  # Cloud execution (50 workers) plan(future_starburst, workers = 50) system.time({   results_cloud <- future_map(1:100, expensive_simulation) }) #> ~2 minutes (including 45s startup) #> Cost: ~$0.85  # Results are identical identical(results_local, results_cloud) #> [1] TRUE

title: Getting Started with staRburst
text: Performance: - Local (single core): ~4 hours - Cloud (100 workers): ~3 minutes - Cost: ~$1.80
code: library(starburst) library(furrr)  # Simulate portfolio returns simulate_portfolio <- function(seed) {   set.seed(seed)      # Random walk for 252 trading days   returns <- rnorm(252, mean = 0.0003, sd = 0.02)   prices <- cumprod(1 + returns)      list(     final_value = prices[252],     max_drawdown = max(cummax(prices) - prices) / max(prices),     sharpe_ratio = mean(returns) / sd(returns) * sqrt(252)   ) }  # Run 10,000 simulations on 100 workers plan(future_starburst, workers = 100)  results <- future_map(1:10000, simulate_portfolio, .options = furrr_options(seed = TRUE))  # Analyze results final_values <- sapply(results, `[[`, "final_value") hist(final_values, breaks = 50, main = "Distribution of Portfolio Final Values")  # 95% confidence interval quantile(final_values, c(0.025, 0.975))

title: Getting Started with staRburst
code: library(starburst) library(furrr)  # Your data data <- read.csv("my_data.csv")  # Bootstrap function bootstrap_regression <- function(i, data) {   # Resample with replacement   boot_indices <- sample(nrow(data), replace = TRUE)   boot_data <- data[boot_indices, ]      # Fit model   model <- lm(y ~ x1 + x2 + x3, data = boot_data)      # Return coefficients   coef(model) }  # Run 10,000 bootstrap samples plan(future_starburst, workers = 50)  boot_results <- future_map(1:10000, bootstrap_regression, data = data)  # Convert to matrix boot_coefs <- do.call(rbind, boot_results)  # 95% confidence intervals for each coefficient apply(boot_coefs, 2, quantile, probs = c(0.025, 0.975))

title: Getting Started with staRburst
text: Performance: - Local (sequential): ~208 hours (8.7 days) - Cloud (100 workers): ~2 hours - Cost: ~$47
code: library(starburst) library(furrr)  # Process one sample process_sample <- function(sample_id) {   # Read from S3 (data already in cloud)   fastq_path <- sprintf("s3://my-genomics-data/samples/%s.fastq", sample_id)   data <- read_fastq(fastq_path)      # Align reads   aligned <- align_reads(data, reference = "hg38")      # Call variants   variants <- call_variants(aligned)      # Return summary   list(     sample_id = sample_id,     num_variants = nrow(variants),     variants = variants   ) }  # Process 1000 samples on 100 workers sample_ids <- list.files("s3://my-genomics-data/samples/", pattern = ".fastq$")  plan(future_starburst, workers = 100)  results <- future_map(sample_ids, process_sample, .progress = TRUE)  # Combine results all_variants <- do.call(rbind, lapply(results, `[[`, "variants"))

title: Getting Started with staRburst
text: data already S3, workers can read directly:
code: plan(future_starburst, workers = 50)  results <- future_map(file_list, function(file) {   # Workers read directly from S3   data <- read.csv(sprintf("s3://my-bucket/%s", file))   process(data) })

title: Getting Started with staRburst
text: smaller datasets, can pass data arguments:
code: # Load data locally data <- read.csv("local_file.csv")  # staRburst automatically uploads to S3 and distributes plan(future_starburst, workers = 50)  results <- future_map(1:1000, function(i) {   # Each worker gets a copy of 'data'   bootstrap_analysis(data, i) })

title: Getting Started with staRburst
text: large objects, pre-upload S3:
code: # Upload once large_data <- read.csv("huge_file.csv") s3_path <- starburst_upload(large_data, "s3://my-bucket/large_data.rds")  # Workers read from S3 plan(future_starburst, workers = 100)  results <- future_map(1:1000, function(i) {   # Read from S3 inside worker   data <- readRDS(s3_path)   process(data, i) })

title: Getting Started with staRburst
code: # Check cost before running plan(future_starburst, workers = 100, cpu = 4, memory = "8GB") #> Estimated cost: ~$3.50/hour

title: Getting Started with staRburst
code: # Set maximum cost per job starburst_config(   max_cost_per_job = 10,      # Don't start jobs that would cost >$10   cost_alert_threshold = 5     # Warn when approaching $5 )  # Now jobs exceeding limit will error before starting plan(future_starburst, workers = 1000)  # Would cost ~$35/hour #> Error: Estimated cost ($35/hr) exceeds limit ($10/hr)

title: Getting Started with staRburst
code: plan(future_starburst, workers = 50)  results <- future_map(data, process)  #> Cluster runtime: 23 minutes #> Total cost: $1.34

title: Getting Started with staRburst
code: starburst_quota_status() #> Fargate vCPU Quota: 100 / 100 used #> Allows: ~25 workers with 4 vCPUs each #> #> Recommended: Request increase to 500 vCPUs

title: Getting Started with staRburst
code: starburst_request_quota_increase(vcpus = 500) #> Requesting Fargate vCPU quota increase: #>   Current: 100 vCPUs #>   Requested: 500 vCPUs #> #> ‚úì Quota increase requested (Case ID: 12345678) #> ‚úì AWS typically approves within 1-24 hours

title: Getting Started with staRburst
text: request workers quota allows, staRburst automatically uses wave-based execution:
code: # Quota allows 25 workers, but you request 100 plan(future_starburst, workers = 100, cpu = 4)  #> ‚ö† Requested: 100 workers (400 vCPUs) #> ‚ö† Current quota: 100 vCPUs (allows 25 workers max) #> #> üìã Execution plan: #>   ‚Ä¢ Running in 4 waves of 25 workers each #> #> üí° Request quota increase to 500 vCPUs? [y/n]: y #> #> ‚úì Quota increase requested #> ‚ö° Starting wave 1 (25 workers)...  results <- future_map(1:1000, expensive_function)  #> ‚ö° Wave 1: 100% complete (250 tasks) #> ‚ö° Wave 2: 100% complete (500 tasks) #> ‚ö° Wave 3: 100% complete (750 tasks) #> ‚ö° Wave 4: 100% complete (1000 tasks)

title: Getting Started with staRburst
code: # View logs from most recent cluster starburst_logs()  # View logs from specific task starburst_logs(task_id = "abc-123")  # View last 100 log lines starburst_logs(last_n = 100)

title: Getting Started with staRburst
code: starburst_status() #> Active Clusters: #>   ‚Ä¢ starburst-xyz123: 50 workers running #>   ‚Ä¢ starburst-abc456: 25 workers running

title: Getting Started with staRburst
text: Environment mismatch: Packages found workers Task failures: tasks failing Slow data transfer: Large objects taking long
code: # Rebuild environment starburst_rebuild_environment() # Check logs starburst_logs(task_id = "failed-task-id")  # Often due to memory limits - increase worker memory plan(future_starburst, workers = 50, memory = "16GB")  # Default is 8GB # Use Arrow for data frames library(arrow) write_parquet(my_data, "s3://bucket/data.parquet")  # Workers read Arrow results <- future_map(1:100, function(i) {   data <- read_parquet("s3://bucket/data.parquet")   process(data, i) })

title: Getting Started with staRburst
text: ‚úÖ Good: task takes >5 minutes ‚ùå Bad: task takes <1 minute
code: # 100 tasks, each takes 10 minutes # Local: 1000 minutes, Cloud: ~10 minutes # 10000 tasks, each takes 30 seconds # Startup overhead (45s) dominates

title: Getting Started with staRburst
text: Instead : :
code: # 10,000 tiny tasks results <- future_map(1:10000, small_function) # 100 batches of 100 tasks each batches <- split(1:10000, ceiling(seq_along(1:10000) / 100))  results <- future_map(batches, function(batch) {   lapply(batch, small_function) })  # Flatten results results <- unlist(results, recursive = FALSE)

title: Getting Started with staRburst
text: Don‚Äôt: :
code: big_data <- read.csv("10GB_file.csv")  # Upload for every task results <- future_map(1:1000, function(i) process(big_data, i)) # Upload once to S3 s3_path <- "s3://bucket/big_data.csv" write.csv(big_data, s3_path)  # Workers read from S3 results <- future_map(1:1000, function(i) {   data <- read.csv(s3_path)   process(data, i) })

title: Getting Started with staRburst
code: starburst_config(   max_cost_per_job = 50,           # Prevent accidents   cost_alert_threshold = 25        # Get warned early )

title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: guide covers security considerations deploying using staRburst production environments.

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 1. Credential Management
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: Never hard-code AWS credentials code: ‚Äôs dangerous: - Credentials code can committed version control - Logs may capture environment variables - Code sharing exposes credentials
code: # NEVER DO THIS - credentials exposed in code Sys.setenv(   AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID = "AKIA...",   AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY = "wJalr..." )

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 1. Credential Management
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: running AWS infrastructure (EC2, ECS, Lambda): Benefits: - credential management required - Automatic credential rotation - Fine-grained permissions via IAM policies - Audit trail via CloudTrail Setup: 1. Create IAM role required permissions 2. Attach role EC2 instance ECS task 3. staRburst automatically discovers uses role credentials
code: # No credentials needed - automatically uses instance/task IAM role library(starburst) plan(starburst, workers = 10)

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 1. Credential Management
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: local development, use AWS CLI profiles: Setup:
code: # Credentials stored in ~/.aws/credentials Sys.setenv(AWS_PROFILE = "my-starburst-profile")  library(starburst) plan(starburst, workers = 10) # Configure AWS CLI profile aws configure --profile my-starburst-profile

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 1. Credential Management
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: cross-account access enhanced security: Benefits: - Time-limited credentials (expire 1-12 hours) - Can require MFA sensitive operations - Separate credentials different roles
code: library(paws.security.identity) sts <- paws.security.identity::sts()  # Assume role with MFA credentials <- sts$assume_role(   RoleArn = "arn:aws:iam::123456789012:role/StarburstRole",   RoleSessionName = "starburst-session",   SerialNumber = "arn:aws:iam::123456789012:mfa/user",   TokenCode = "123456"  # MFA token )  # Use temporary credentials Sys.setenv(   AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID = credentials$Credentials$AccessKeyId,   AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY = credentials$Credentials$SecretAccessKey,   AWS_SESSION_TOKEN = credentials$Credentials$SessionToken )

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 2. S3 Bucket Security
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: Create IAM policy staRburst workers:
code: {   "Version": "2012-10-17",   "Statement": [     {       "Sid": "StarburstWorkerAccess",       "Effect": "Allow",       "Action": [         "s3:GetObject",         "s3:PutObject",         "s3:DeleteObject",         "s3:ListBucket"       ],       "Resource": [         "arn:aws:s3:::my-starburst-bucket",         "arn:aws:s3:::my-starburst-bucket/*"       ],       "Condition": {         "StringLike": {           "s3:prefix": ["sessions/*", "tasks/*", "results/*"]         }       }     }   ] }

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 2. S3 Bucket Security
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: Encrypt data rest S3: Encryption Options: - AES256 - S3-managed keys (SSE-S3, free) - aws:kms - AWS KMS managed keys (SSE-KMS, control, costs apply) - aws:kms:dsse - Dual-layer encryption compliance (SSE-KMS-DSSE)
code: # Option 1: Enable default encryption via AWS Console or CLI library(paws.storage) s3 <- paws.storage::s3()  s3$put_bucket_encryption(   Bucket = "my-starburst-bucket",   ServerSideEncryptionConfiguration = list(     Rules = list(       list(         ApplyServerSideEncryptionByDefault = list(           SSEAlgorithm = "AES256"  # Or "aws:kms" for KMS         ),         BucketKeyEnabled = TRUE       )     )   ) )

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 2. S3 Bucket Security
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: Protect accidental deletion: Benefits: - Recover accidental deletions - Rollback previous versions - Required certain compliance frameworks
code: s3$put_bucket_versioning(   Bucket = "my-starburst-bucket",   VersioningConfiguration = list(     Status = "Enabled"   ) )

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 2. S3 Bucket Security
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: Ensure bucket never publicly accessible:
code: s3$put_public_access_block(   Bucket = "my-starburst-bucket",   PublicAccessBlockConfiguration = list(     BlockPublicAcls = TRUE,     IgnorePublicAcls = TRUE,     BlockPublicPolicy = TRUE,     RestrictPublicBuckets = TRUE   ) )

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 2. S3 Bucket Security
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: Restrict access specific IAM roles:
code: {   "Version": "2012-10-17",   "Statement": [     {       "Sid": "DenyUnencryptedObjectUploads",       "Effect": "Deny",       "Principal": "*",       "Action": "s3:PutObject",       "Resource": "arn:aws:s3:::my-starburst-bucket/*",       "Condition": {         "StringNotEquals": {           "s3:x-amz-server-side-encryption": "AES256"         }       }     },     {       "Sid": "DenyInsecureTransport",       "Effect": "Deny",       "Principal": "*",       "Action": "s3:*",       "Resource": "arn:aws:s3:::my-starburst-bucket/*",       "Condition": {         "Bool": {           "aws:SecureTransport": "false"         }       }     }   ] }

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 3. Network Isolation
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: Deploy workers private subnets without internet access: Requirements Private Subnets: - VPC endpoints S3, ECR, CloudWatch Logs - NAT Gateway internet access needed operations
code: library(starburst)  # Configure to use private subnets starburst_config(   subnets = c("subnet-private-1a", "subnet-private-1b"),   security_groups = c("sg-starburst-workers") )  plan(starburst, workers = 10)

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 3. Network Isolation
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: Minimal security group (inbound, outbound):
code: {   "GroupName": "starburst-workers",   "Description": "Security group for staRburst ECS tasks",   "VpcId": "vpc-...",   "SecurityGroupIngress": [],   "SecurityGroupEgress": [     {       "IpProtocol": "tcp",       "FromPort": 443,       "ToPort": 443,       "CidrIp": "0.0.0.0/0",       "Description": "HTTPS to AWS services"     }   ] }

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 3. Network Isolation
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: Avoid internet traffic AWS service calls: S3 Gateway Endpoint (free): ECR Interface Endpoints (charges apply): CloudWatch Logs Endpoint: Benefits: - AWS API traffic stays within AWS network - Reduced data transfer costs - Better security posture (internet exposure)
code: aws ec2 create-vpc-endpoint \   --vpc-id vpc-... \   --service-name com.amazonaws.us-east-1.s3 \   --route-table-ids rtb-... # ECR API endpoint aws ec2 create-vpc-endpoint \   --vpc-id vpc-... \   --service-name com.amazonaws.us-east-1.ecr.api \   --vpc-endpoint-type Interface \   --subnet-ids subnet-... \   --security-group-ids sg-...  # ECR Docker endpoint aws ec2 create-vpc-endpoint \   --vpc-id vpc-... \   --service-name com.amazonaws.us-east-1.ecr.dkr \   --vpc-endpoint-type Interface \   --subnet-ids subnet-... \   --security-group-ids sg-... aws ec2 create-vpc-endpoint \   --vpc-id vpc-... \   --service-name com.amazonaws.us-east-1.logs \   --vpc-endpoint-type Interface \   --subnet-ids subnet-... \   --security-group-ids sg-...

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 4. Cost Controls
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: Create AWS Budget monitor staRburst costs: Go AWS Billing Console ‚Üí Budgets Click Create budget Choose Cost budget Set monthly budget (e.g., $500) 50% actual spend ‚Üí Email warning 80% actual spend ‚Üí Email alert 100% actual spend ‚Üí Email urgent alert + SNS notification

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 4. Cost Controls
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: staRburst enforces maximum 500 workers per plan:
code: # This will error - prevents accidental huge deployments plan(starburst, workers = 10000) # Error: Workers must be <= 500  # Maximum allowed plan(starburst, workers = 500)

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 4. Cost Controls
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: Regularly check orphaned sessions:
code: # List all sessions sessions <- starburst_list_sessions() print(sessions)  # Cleanup old sessions for (session_id in sessions$session_id) {   # Check if session is old   created_date <- as.Date(sessions$created_at[sessions$session_id == session_id])   if (Sys.Date() - created_date > 7) {     cat(sprintf("Cleaning up old session: %s\n", session_id))     session <- starburst_session_attach(session_id)     session$cleanup(stop_workers = TRUE, force = TRUE)   } }

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 4. Cost Controls
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: Prevent sessions running indefinitely:
code: # Session auto-terminates after 24 hours session <- starburst_session(   workers = 10,   absolute_timeout = 86400  # 24 hours in seconds )

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 4. Cost Controls
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: launching large jobs:
code: # Estimate cost workers <- 100 cpu <- 4 memory_gb <- 8 runtime_hours <- 2  # Fargate pricing (us-east-1, 2026) vcpu_price <- 0.04048 memory_price <- 0.004445  cost_per_worker <- (cpu * vcpu_price) + (memory_gb * memory_price) total_cost <- workers * cost_per_worker * runtime_hours  cat(sprintf("Estimated cost: $%.2f for %d hours\n", total_cost, runtime_hours)) # Estimated cost: $19.84 for 2 hours

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 5. Audit Logging
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: Capture API calls security auditing: AWS Console ‚Üí CloudTrail Create trail Apply regions Enable management events Enable data events (optional, S3 object-level logging) CloudTrail Captures: - launched staRburst workers (IAM user/role) - tasks created/stopped - S3 object access (data events enabled) - API failures authorization errors

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 5. Audit Logging
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: staRburst automatically logs CloudWatch: Log Group: /aws/ecs/starburst-worker Retention: 7 days (default) Increase retention compliance:
code: library(paws.management) logs <- paws.management::cloudwatchlogs()  logs$put_retention_policy(   logGroupName = "/aws/ecs/starburst-worker",   retentionInDays = 30  # or 90, 180, 365, etc. )

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 5. Audit Logging
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: Track S3 bucket access: Access logs include: - accessed objects - objects accessed - operations performed - Source IP addresses
code: s3$put_bucket_logging(   Bucket = "my-starburst-bucket",   BucketLoggingStatus = list(     LoggingEnabled = list(       TargetBucket = "my-logging-bucket",       TargetPrefix = "starburst-access-logs/"     )   ) )

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 5. Audit Logging
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: Regularly review logs suspicious activity:
code: # CloudWatch Insights query for failed authentications library(paws.management) logs <- paws.management::cloudwatchlogs()  # Query for errors in last 24 hours query <- "fields @timestamp, @message | filter @message like /ERROR|AccessDenied|Forbidden/ | sort @timestamp desc"  start_time <- as.integer(Sys.time() - 86400)  # 24 hours ago end_time <- as.integer(Sys.time())  result <- logs$start_query(   logGroupName = "/aws/ecs/starburst-worker",   startTime = start_time,   endTime = end_time,   queryString = query )

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 6. Data Protection
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: send necessary data workers:
code: # ‚úÖ Good - only send needed data large_data <- read.csv("huge_dataset.csv") sample_data <- large_data[1:1000, ]  # Use sample for testing  plan(starburst, workers = 10) results <- future_map(1:10, function(i) {   # sample_data automatically uploaded as global   analyze(sample_data[i, ]) })  # ‚ùå Bad - sends entire large dataset plan(starburst, workers = 10) results <- future_map(1:10, function(i) {   analyze(large_data[i, ])  # Uploads all of large_data })

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 6. Data Protection
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
code: # Collect and immediately delete from S3 session <- starburst_session(workers = 10) task_id <- session$submit(quote(sensitive_computation()))  # Wait for completion results <- session$collect(wait = TRUE)  # Immediately cleanup (force = TRUE deletes S3 files) session$cleanup(force = TRUE)  # Save results locally if needed saveRDS(results, "local_results.rds")

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 6. Data Protection
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: highly sensitive data:
code: # Encrypt before upload library(sodium)  # Generate key (store securely, e.g., AWS Secrets Manager) key <- random(32)  # Encrypt data before passing to future sensitive_data <- serialize(my_data, NULL) encrypted_data <- data_encrypt(sensitive_data, key)  # Run computation plan(starburst, workers = 1) result <- future({   # Decrypt in worker   decrypted <- data_decrypt(encrypted_data, key)   my_data <- unserialize(decrypted)   # Process... })

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 7. Container Image Security
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: staRburst uses multi-stage builds minimize image size: Base image includes essential R packages Project images layer top base Smaller images = fewer potential vulnerabilities

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 7. Container Image Security
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: Enable ECR image scanning:
code: library(paws.compute) ecr <- paws.compute::ecr()  ecr$put_image_scanning_configuration(   repositoryName = "starburst-worker",   imageScanningConfiguration = list(     scanOnPush = TRUE   ) )

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 7. Container Image Security
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: Automatically delete old images:
code: # Delete images older than 30 days ecr$put_lifecycle_policy(   repositoryName = "starburst-worker",   lifecyclePolicyText = jsonlite::toJSON(list(     rules = list(       list(         rulePriority = 1,         description = "Delete old images",         selection = list(           tagStatus = "any",           countType = "sinceImagePushed",           countUnit = "days",           countNumber = 30         ),         action = list(type = "expire")       )     )   ), auto_unbox = TRUE) )

title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: HIPAA-regulated workloads: Sign AWS Business Associate Agreement (BAA) Use HIPAA-eligible services (Fargate, S3, ECR eligible) Enable encryption rest (S3, EBS) transit (TLS) Enable audit logging (CloudTrail, CloudWatch Logs) Implement access controls (IAM, VPC, Security Groups) Use private subnets VPC endpoints

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 8. Compliance Considerations
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: EU data processing: Use EU regions (eu-west-1, eu-central-1, etc.) Enable encryption data rest transit Implement data retention policies (auto-delete N days) Enable audit logging data access Document data processing activities Implement right erasure (cleanup mechanisms)

title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: SOC 2 compliance: Enable CloudTrail regions Enable AWS Config configuration compliance Use AWS Organizations multi-account management Implement least-privilege IAM policies Enable MFA IAM users Review access quarterly

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 9. Incident Response
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: Immediate Actions: 1. Disable/rotate credentials immediately 2. Review CloudTrail logs unauthorized activity 3. Check new resources created attacker 4. Terminate suspicious ECS tasks 5. Review S3 bucket access logs
code: # List all active sessions sessions <- starburst_list_sessions()  # Check for sessions you didn't create print(sessions)  # Cleanup suspicious sessions for (session_id in suspicious_ids) {   session <- starburst_session_attach(session_id)   session$cleanup(stop_workers = TRUE, force = TRUE) }

previous_headings: Security Best Practices for staRburst > 9. Incident Response
title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: Isolate affected resources (change security groups) Review S3 access logs unauthorized downloads Check CloudTrail API calls Preserve evidence (don‚Äôt delete logs) Notify security team legal counsel Follow incident response plan

title: Security Best Practices for staRburst
text: deploying staRburst production: Use IAM roles instead long-term credentials Enable S3 bucket encryption (SSE-S3 SSE-KMS) Enable S3 versioning Block public access S3 bucket Use private subnets sensitive workloads Configure VPC endpoints AWS services Create security group minimal permissions Enable CloudTrail regions Enable CloudWatch Logs appropriate retention Set AWS Budget alerts Limit maximum workers prevent runaway costs Enable ECR image scanning Implement image lifecycle policies Document data classification handling Train team security best practices Establish incident response procedures Review IAM policies quarterly Test backup recovery procedures

title: Troubleshooting staRburst
text: staRburst automatically sends worker logs CloudWatch Logs: Log Group: /aws/ecs/starburst-worker Log Stream Pattern: starburst/<task-id> Retention: 7 days (configurable)

title: Troubleshooting staRburst
code: # For ephemeral mode library(starburst) plan(starburst, workers = 10)  # Check logs for a specific task # (get task ID from error messages or futures)  # For detached sessions session <- starburst_session_attach("session-id") status <- session$status()  # View failed task logs using AWS CLI or console

title: Troubleshooting staRburst
text: Navigate CloudWatch ‚Üí Log Groups Find /aws/ecs/starburst-worker Search task ID stream names Use CloudWatch Insights advanced queries:
code: fields @timestamp, @message | filter @message like /ERROR/ | sort @timestamp desc | limit 100

title: Troubleshooting staRburst
text: Symptoms: - session$status() shows tasks never start - Workers = 0 status - Tasks remain pending state >5 minutes Diagnosis: Common Causes: Default Fargate quota: 6 vCPUs us-east-1 worker uses configured CPU (default: 4 vCPUs) 10 workers √ó 4 vCPUs = 40 vCPUs needed Fargate strict CPU/memory pairings Example: 4 vCPUs supports 8-30 GB memory Subnets must available IP addresses Security groups must allow outbound traffic Must ECR, S3, CloudWatch Logs access Solutions:
code: # Check Fargate quota config <- get_starburst_config() sts <- paws.security.identity::sts() account <- sts$get_caller_identity()  # Check service quotas manually in AWS Console: # Service Quotas ‚Üí AWS Fargate ‚Üí Fargate vCPUs # Solution 1: Request quota increase # Go to AWS Console ‚Üí Service Quotas ‚Üí AWS Fargate # Request vCPUs quota increase to 100+  # Solution 2: Reduce workers plan(starburst, workers = 1)  # Use only 1 worker (4 vCPUs)  # Solution 3: Reduce CPU per worker plan(starburst, workers = 10, cpu = 0.25, memory = "512MB")  # Solution 4: Check IAM permissions # Ensure ECS task execution role has: # - AmazonECSTaskExecutionRolePolicy # - S3 read/write access to starburst bucket # - CloudWatch Logs write access

title: Troubleshooting staRburst
text: Symptoms: - Tasks start stop within 30 seconds - Status shows workers = 0 initial launch - CloudWatch logs show error exit Diagnosis: Common Causes: S3 permission errors - Task role can‚Äôt access bucket Package installation failures - Missing system dependencies memory - Memory limit low workload Architecture mismatch - ARM64 vs X86_64 image/instance mismatch Solutions:
code: # View CloudWatch logs for the failed task # Look for error messages in the logs  # Common error patterns: # - "Error: Cannot connect to S3" ‚Üí S3 permissions # - "Error loading package" ‚Üí Package installation failed # - "Cannot allocate memory" ‚Üí Memory limit too low # - "exec format error" ‚Üí Architecture mismatch # Solution 1: Verify S3 permissions # Check task role has S3 access: # IAM ‚Üí Roles ‚Üí starburstECSTaskRole ‚Üí Permissions # Should have S3 GetObject/PutObject on bucket  # Solution 2: Increase memory plan(starburst, workers = 5, cpu = 4, memory = "16GB")  # Solution 3: Check Docker build logs # Re-run starburst setup to rebuild image # Watch for package installation errors  # Solution 4: For EC2 mode, verify architecture matches plan(starburst,      launch_type = "EC2",      instance_type = "c7g.xlarge")  # Graviton (ARM64) # Ensure Docker image built for matching architecture

title: Troubleshooting staRburst
text: Symptoms: - Error messages containing ‚ÄúAccessDenied‚Äù ‚ÄúForbidden‚Äù - Can‚Äôt create tasks, access S3, push Docker images Diagnosis: Common Causes: AWS credentials configured IAM user lacks required permissions S3 bucket policy blocks access ECR repository doesn‚Äôt exist blocks access Solutions:
code: # Check which operation is failing: # 1. Docker push ‚Üí ECR permissions # 2. S3 operations ‚Üí S3 permissions # 3. Task launch ‚Üí ECS permissions  # Verify credentials library(paws.security.identity) sts <- paws.security.identity::sts() identity <- sts$get_caller_identity() print(identity)  # Should show your AWS account # Solution 1: Configure AWS credentials # Option A: Environment variables Sys.setenv(   AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID = "YOUR_KEY",   AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY = "YOUR_SECRET",   AWS_DEFAULT_REGION = "us-east-1" )  # Option B: AWS CLI profile Sys.setenv(AWS_PROFILE = "your-profile")  # Option C: IAM role (when running on EC2/ECS) # No configuration needed - automatic  # Solution 2: Add required IAM permissions # Your IAM user/role needs: # - ECS: RunTask, DescribeTasks, StopTask # - ECR: GetAuthorizationToken, BatchCheckLayerAvailability, #        GetDownloadUrlForLayer, PutImage, InitiateLayerUpload, etc. # - S3: GetObject, PutObject, ListBucket on your bucket # - IAM: PassRole (to pass ECS task role)  # Solution 3: Run starburst_setup() to create all resources library(starburst) starburst_setup(bucket = "my-starburst-bucket")

title: Troubleshooting staRburst
text: Symptoms: - AWS bill higher expected - Many tasks running expected stop - Old sessions still active workers Diagnosis: Common Causes: Forgot cleanup session - Workers keep running Requested many workers - Cost adds quickly Long-running tasks - Tasks running hours/days Solutions:
code: # List all active sessions library(starburst) sessions <- starburst_list_sessions() print(sessions)  # Check for old sessions with running tasks # Solution 1: Cleanup all sessions sessions <- starburst_list_sessions() for (session_id in sessions$session_id) {   session <- starburst_session_attach(session_id)   session$cleanup(stop_workers = TRUE, force = TRUE) }  # Solution 2: Set budget alerts in AWS # AWS Billing Console ‚Üí Budgets ‚Üí Create budget # Set alert at $100, $500 thresholds  # Solution 3: Use worker validation to prevent mistakes # staRburst now enforces max 500 workers # Previously you could accidentally request 10,000+  # Solution 4: Set absolute timeout on sessions session <- starburst_session(   workers = 10,   absolute_timeout = 3600  # Auto-terminate after 1 hour )

title: Troubleshooting staRburst
text: Symptoms: - Called session$cleanup() workers still running - S3 files deleted - Tasks still appearing ECS console Diagnosis: Common Causes: Cleanup called without stop_workers - Workers stopped Cleanup called without force - S3 files preserved Tasks different cluster - Cleanup looking wrong place ECS eventual consistency - Tasks take time stop Solutions:
code: # Check if cleanup was called with correct parameters session$cleanup(stop_workers = TRUE, force = TRUE)  # Verify tasks actually stopped (may take 30-60 seconds) Sys.sleep(60)  # Check ECS tasks manually library(paws.compute) ecs <- paws.compute::ecs(config = list(region = "us-east-1")) tasks <- ecs$list_tasks(cluster = "starburst-cluster") print(tasks$taskArns)  # Should be empty or not include your tasks # Solution 1: Always use both flags for full cleanup session$cleanup(stop_workers = TRUE, force = TRUE)  # Solution 2: Wait for ECS to process stop requests session$cleanup(stop_workers = TRUE) Sys.sleep(60)  # Wait 1 minute # Then verify in AWS console  # Solution 3: Manual cleanup if needed library(paws.compute) library(paws.storage)  ecs <- paws.compute::ecs(config = list(region = "us-east-1")) s3 <- paws.storage::s3(config = list(region = "us-east-1"))  # Stop all tasks in cluster tasks <- ecs$list_tasks(cluster = "starburst-cluster", desiredStatus = "RUNNING") for (task_arn in tasks$taskArns) {   ecs$stop_task(cluster = "starburst-cluster", task = task_arn) }  # Delete all session S3 files result <- s3$list_objects_v2(Bucket = "your-bucket", Prefix = "sessions/") # ... delete objects

title: Troubleshooting staRburst
text: Symptoms: - session$collect() returns empty list - Tasks show ‚Äúcompleted‚Äù results - S3 doesn‚Äôt contain result files Diagnosis: Common Causes: Tasks failed producing results - Check errors Workers can‚Äôt write S3 - Permission issue Looking wrong session ID - Attached wrong session Results already collected - Results collected Solutions:
code: # Check session status status <- session$status() print(status)  # Verify tasks were actually submitted # Check S3 for task files library(paws.storage) s3 <- paws.storage::s3(config = list(region = "us-east-1")) result <- s3$list_objects_v2(   Bucket = "your-bucket",   Prefix = sprintf("sessions/%s/results/", session$session_id) ) print(result$Contents)  # Should show .qs files # Solution 1: Check task status for errors status <- session$status() if (status$failed_tasks > 0) {   # Check CloudWatch logs for failed task IDs   # Look for error messages }  # Solution 2: Verify S3 write permissions # Task role must have S3 PutObject permission  # Solution 3: Verify session ID print(session$session_id) # Make sure this matches the session you created  # Solution 4: Results can only be collected once # If you already called collect(), results are removed from S3 # You should store results after collection: results <- session$collect(wait = TRUE) saveRDS(results, "my_results.rds")  # Save locally

title: Troubleshooting staRburst
text: Symptoms: - starburst_session_attach() throws error - ‚ÄúSession found‚Äù message - Can‚Äôt reconnect closing R Diagnosis: Common Causes: Wrong session ID - Typo wrong ID Session expired - Exceeded absolute_timeout S3 manifest deleted - Someone deleted session files Wrong region - Session created different region Solutions:
code: # List all sessions to find your session ID sessions <- starburst_list_sessions() print(sessions)  # Try to attach with exact session ID session_id <- "session-abc123..." session <- starburst_session_attach(session_id) # Solution 1: List and copy exact session ID sessions <- starburst_list_sessions() session_id <- sessions$session_id[1]  # Use exact ID session <- starburst_session_attach(session_id)  # Solution 2: Save session ID immediately after creation session <- starburst_session(workers = 10) session_id <- session$session_id write(session_id, "my_session_id.txt")  # Save to file # Later: session_id <- readLines("my_session_id.txt") session <- starburst_session_attach(session_id)  # Solution 3: Check correct region session <- starburst_session_attach(session_id, region = "us-west-2")

title: Troubleshooting staRburst
text: Symptoms: - Docker build fails renv::restore() - Error messages missing system dependencies - Specific packages fail install Diagnosis: Look Docker build output running staRburst. Common error patterns: Common Causes: Missing system dependencies - Package needs system libraries Package CRAN - Private development package Version conflicts - renv.lock specifies unavailable version Solutions:
code: Error: installation of package 'X' had non-zero exit status Error: compilation failed for package 'X' Error: unable to load shared library # Solution 1: Add system dependencies to Dockerfile.base # Edit starburst package Dockerfile.base template: # Add RUN apt-get install -y libcurl4-openssl-dev  # Solution 2: Use renv snapshot to capture dependencies renv::snapshot()  # Updates renv.lock  # Solution 3: Install from GitHub for dev packages renv::install("user/package") renv::snapshot()  # Solution 4: Check package availability install.packages("package")  # Test locally first

title: Troubleshooting staRburst
code: library(paws.compute) ecs <- paws.compute::ecs(config = list(region = "us-east-1"))  # List all tasks tasks <- ecs$list_tasks(   cluster = "starburst-cluster",   desiredStatus = "RUNNING" )  # Describe specific task task_detail <- ecs$describe_tasks(   cluster = "starburst-cluster",   tasks = tasks$taskArns[1:1] )  # Check exit code and reason print(task_detail$tasks[[1]]$containers[[1]]$exitCode) print(task_detail$tasks[[1]]$stoppedReason)

title: Troubleshooting staRburst
code: library(paws.storage) s3 <- paws.storage::s3(config = list(region = "us-east-1"))  # List all session files result <- s3$list_objects_v2(   Bucket = "your-starburst-bucket",   Prefix = "sessions/" )  # Calculate total storage total_bytes <- sum(sapply(result$Contents, function(x) x$Size)) total_mb <- total_bytes / 1024^2 cat(sprintf("Total storage: %.2f MB\n", total_mb))

title: Troubleshooting staRburst
code: # Fargate pricing (us-east-1, 2026): # - vCPU: $0.04048 per hour # - Memory: $0.004445 per GB-hour  vcpu_price <- 0.04048 memory_price <- 0.004445  workers <- 10 cpu <- 4 memory_gb <- 8 runtime_hours <- 1  cost_per_worker <- (cpu * vcpu_price) + (memory_gb * memory_price) total_cost <- workers * cost_per_worker * runtime_hours  cat(sprintf("Estimated cost: $%.2f for %d hours\n", total_cost, runtime_hours))

what: staRburst ‚Ä¢ Seamless AWS Cloud Bursting for R
title: staRburst ‚Ä¢ Seamless AWS Cloud Bursting for R
text: Seamless AWS cloud bursting parallel R workloads staRburst lets run parallel R code AWS zero infrastructure management. Scale laptop 100+ cloud workers single function call. Supports EC2 (recommended performance cost) Fargate (serverless) backends.

title: staRburst ‚Ä¢ Seamless AWS Cloud Bursting for R
text: Simple Setup: One-time configuration (~2 minutes), seamless operation Simple API: Direct starburst_map() function - new concepts learn Flexible Backends: EC2 (recommended - faster, cheaper, spot support) Fargate (serverless) Detached Sessions: Submit long-running jobs detach - retrieve results anytime Automatic Environment Sync: packages dependencies automatically available workers Smart Quota Management: Automatically handles AWS quota limits wave execution Cost Transparent: See estimated actual costs every run Auto Cleanup: Workers shut automatically done

title: staRburst ‚Ä¢ Seamless AWS Cloud Bursting for R

title: staRburst ‚Ä¢ Seamless AWS Cloud Bursting for R
code: library(starburst)  # One-time setup (2 minutes) starburst_setup()  # Run parallel computation on AWS results <- starburst_map(   1:1000,   function(x) expensive_computation(x),   workers = 50 ) #> üöÄ Starting starburst cluster with 50 workers #> üí∞ Estimated cost: ~$2.80/hour #> üìä Processing 1000 items with 50 workers #> üì¶ Created 50 chunks (avg 20 items per chunk) #> üöÄ Submitting tasks... #> ‚úì Submitted 50 tasks #> ‚è≥ Progress: 50/50 tasks (3.2 minutes elapsed) #> #> ‚úì Completed in 3.2 minutes #> üí∞ Estimated cost: $0.15

title: staRburst ‚Ä¢ Seamless AWS Cloud Bursting for R
code: library(starburst)  # Define simulation simulate_portfolio <- function(seed) {   set.seed(seed)   returns <- rnorm(252, mean = 0.0003, sd = 0.02)   prices <- cumprod(1 + returns)    list(     final_value = prices[252],     sharpe_ratio = mean(returns) / sd(returns) * sqrt(252)   ) }  # Run 10,000 simulations on 100 AWS workers results <- starburst_map(   1:10000,   simulate_portfolio,   workers = 100 ) #> üöÄ Starting starburst cluster with 100 workers #> üí∞ Estimated cost: ~$5.60/hour #> üìä Processing 10000 items with 100 workers #> ‚è≥ Progress: 100/100 tasks (3.1 minutes elapsed) #> #> ‚úì Completed in 3.1 minutes #> üí∞ Estimated cost: $0.29  # Extract results final_values <- sapply(results, function(x) x$final_value) sharpe_ratios <- sapply(results, function(x) x$sharpe_ratio)  # Summary mean(final_values)    # Average portfolio outcome quantile(final_values, c(0.05, 0.95))  # Risk range  # Comparison: # Local (single core): ~4 hours # Cloud (100 workers): 3 minutes, $0.29

title: staRburst ‚Ä¢ Seamless AWS Cloud Bursting for R
text: Run long jobs disconnect - results persist S3:
code: # Start detached session session <- starburst_session(workers = 50, detached = TRUE)  # Submit work and get session ID session$submit(quote({   results <- starburst_map(huge_dataset, expensive_function)   saveRDS(results, "results.rds") })) session_id <- session$session_id  # Disconnect - job continues running # Later (hours/days), reconnect: session <- starburst_session_attach(session_id) status <- session$status()  # Check progress results <- session$collect()  # Get results  # Cleanup when done session$cleanup(force = TRUE)

title: staRburst ‚Ä¢ Seamless AWS Cloud Bursting for R
text: Environment Snapshot: Captures R packages using renv Container Build: Creates Docker image environment, cached ECR Task Distribution: Splits data chunks across workers Task Submission: Launches Fargate tasks (sequential batches quota-limited) Data Transfer: Serializes task data S3 using fast qs format Execution: Workers pull data, execute function chunk items, push results Result Collection: Downloads combines results correct order Cleanup: Automatically shuts workers

title: staRburst ‚Ä¢ Seamless AWS Cloud Bursting for R
code: # Set cost limits starburst_config(   max_cost_per_job = 10,      # Hard limit   cost_alert_threshold = 5     # Warning at $5 )  # Costs shown transparently results <- starburst_map(data, fn, workers = 100) #> üí∞ Estimated cost: ~$3.50/hour #> ‚úì Completed in 23 minutes #> üí∞ Estimated cost: $1.34

title: staRburst ‚Ä¢ Seamless AWS Cloud Bursting for R
text: staRburst automatically handles AWS Fargate quota limitations: work still completes, just fewer workers. can request quota increases AWS Service Quotas.
code: results <- starburst_map(data, fn, workers = 100, cpu = 4) #> ‚ö† Requested 100 workers (400 vCPUs) but quota allows 25 workers (100 vCPUs) #> ‚ö† Using 25 workers instead #> üí∞ Estimated cost: ~$1.40/hour

text: workers Number parallel workers (default: 10) cpu vCPUs per worker (default: 4) memory Memory per worker, e.g., "8GB" (default: "8GB") region AWS region (default: config "us-east-1") timeout Task timeout seconds (default: 3600) session_timeout Active timeout seconds (default: 3600) absolute_timeout Maximum session lifetime seconds (default: 86400) launch_type "FARGATE" "EC2" (default: "FARGATE") instance_type EC2 instance type EC2 launch (default: "c6a.large") use_spot Use spot instances EC2 (default: FALSE) warm_pool_timeout EC2 warm pool timeout seconds (default: 3600)

title: Setup staRburst ‚Äî starburst_setup
text: One-time configuration set AWS resources staRburst

title: Setup staRburst ‚Äî starburst_setup
code: starburst_setup(   region = "us-east-1",   force = FALSE,   use_public_base = TRUE,   ecr_image_ttl_days = NULL )

title: Setup staRburst ‚Äî starburst_setup
text: region AWS region (default: "us-east-1") force Force re-setup even already configured use_public_base Use public base Docker images (default: TRUE). Set FALSE build private base images ECR. ecr_image_ttl_days Number days keep Docker images ECR (default: NULL = never delete). AWS automatically delete images older many days. prevents surprise costs stop using staRburst. Recommended: 30 days regular users, 7 days occasional users. images deleted, rebuilt next use (adds 3-5 min).

title: Setup staRburst ‚Äî starburst_setup
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Default: keep images forever (~$0.50/month idle cost) starburst_setup()  # Auto-delete images after 30 days (saves money if you stop using it) starburst_setup(ecr_image_ttl_days = 30)  # Use private base images with 7-day cleanup starburst_setup(use_public_base = FALSE, ecr_image_ttl_days = 7) } # }

code: At 45s local might be at iteration 50. You could transfer that state and have cloud continue from iteration 51. But the overhead of serialization + transfer probably eats any gain.  ## Better Speculative Strategy  **Simple race**: - Both start from scratch - First to finish wins, kill the other - Accept that one will be wasted compute  **Why this is fine**: - 45s of local compute on your 16-core workstation ‚âà $0.00 (already paid for) - If local finishes in <2min, cloud never gets used (Fargate billed per-second, minimal cost) - If job takes 30min, wasting 45s of local compute is noise  **When to use which**:

[y/n] Matters Without quota handling: User: ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt work, got weird errors‚Äù Reality: Hit quota, partial failure, confusing Outcome: Abandoned tool, bad review quota handling: User: ‚ÄúAsked 100 workers, quota allowed 25, tool told fix ‚Äù Reality: Transparent, helpful, actionable Outcome: User requests quota increase, comes back, succeeds Check CI/Testing r # test suite test_that(‚Äúquota checks work‚Äù, { # Mock quota API quota <- 100 plan <- plan_starburst(workers = 50, cpu = 4) # needs 200 expect_warning(‚Äúquota‚Äù) expect_equal(plan$actual_workers, 25) # graceful degradation }) Documentation Critical Section README.md: markdown ### AWS Quotas staRburst requires sufficient AWS Fargate vCPU quota. Check quota: - Visit AWS Console > Service Quotas > Fargate - run: starburst_quota_status() Typical quotas: - New accounts: 100 vCPUs (allows ~25 workers) - increase: 500-1000 vCPUs (allows 100+ workers) Request increase: 1. Automatic: starburst_request_quota_increase(vcpus = 500) 2. Manual: [AWS Console instructions] Approval usually takes 1-24 hours. know pain intimately AWS work - users hitting quotas #1 support issue AWS tool. Handle proactively staRburst 10x better alternatives. ‚Äôs experience quota issues AWS? patterns ‚Äôve seen handling gracefully? Wave based sure plus ask make quota increase request user Jan 31 Validated wave-based execution strategy proactive quota assistance approach Perfect. ‚Äôs right UX. Let sketch flow: Ideal User Experience First-time user, low quota: r library(starburst) plan(future_starburst, workers = 100, cpu = 4) ‚ö° Checking Fargate capacity‚Ä¶ ‚ö† Requested: 100 workers (400 vCPUs) ‚ö† Current quota: 100 vCPUs (allows 25 workers max) üìã Execution plan: ‚Ä¢ Running 4 waves 25 workers ‚Ä¢ Wave 1: starts immediately ‚Ä¢ Waves 2-4: start workers complete ‚Ä¢ Estimated total time: ~100 parallel + 3x startup overhead üí° Quota increase recommended: Request 500 vCPU quota? (usually approved 1-24 hours) [y/n]: y ‚úì Quota increase requested (Case ID: 12345678) ‚úì ‚Äôll receive email approved ‚úì Future runs use full parallelism ‚ö° Starting wave 1 (25 workers)‚Ä¶ User just says yes , problem solved forever. Implementation Quota check automatic fallback: r plan.starburst <- function(workers = 10, cpu = 4, memory = ‚Äú8GB‚Äù, ‚Ä¶) { # Check quota quota_info <- check_fargate_quota() vcpus_needed <- workers * cpu vcpus_available <- quota_info$limit (vcpus_needed > vcpus_available) { # Calculate wave-based execution workers_per_wave <- floor(vcpus_available / cpu) num_waves <- ceiling(workers / workers_per_wave) } else { # Sufficient quota plan <- list( workers = workers, workers_per_wave = workers, num_waves = 1, cpu = cpu, memory = memory, quota_limited = FALSE ) } structure(plan, class = c(‚Äústarburst‚Äù, ‚Äúcluster‚Äù, ‚Äúfuture‚Äù)) } Wave Execution tasks submitted: r # User code results <- future_map(samples, expensive_analysis)

text: submit_tasks_with_waves <- function(tasks, plan) { (plan$quota_limited) { # Queue-based execution task_queue <- tasks results <- list() } else { # Normal parallel execution # tasks } } Smart Quota Suggestions r suggest_quota <- function(needed_vcpus) { # Round reasonable increments # AWS likes: 100, 200, 500, 1000, 2000, 5000 (needed_vcpus <= 200) return(200) (needed_vcpus <= 500) return(500) (needed_vcpus <= 1000) return(1000) (needed_vcpus <= 2000) return(2000) return(5000) } Reasoning: Ask need now, don‚Äôt hit limit soon. need 400, request 500. Non-Interactive Mode scripts/automation: r # automated script plan(future_starburst, workers = 100, auto_quota_request = TRUE) # Don‚Äôt prompt, just request
code: for (wave in 1:plan$num_waves) {   cat_info(sprintf("‚ö° Starting wave %d of %d (%d workers)...\n",                    wave, plan$num_waves, plan$workers_per_wave))      # Launch workers for this wave   wave_tasks <- head(task_queue, plan$workers_per_wave)   task_queue <- tail(task_queue, -plan$workers_per_wave)      # Submit to Fargate   wave_futures <- lapply(wave_tasks, submit_to_fargate)      # Wait for wave to complete   wave_results <- lapply(wave_futures, value)   results <- c(results, wave_results)      # Progress   cat_success(sprintf("‚úì Wave %d complete (%d/%d tasks done)\n",                      wave, length(results), length(tasks))) }

üí° typical parallel workloads, recommend 500+ vCPUs
")     cat_info(sprintf("   current quota (%d) allows ~%d workers 4 vCPUs 
",                     quota_info$limit, floor(quota_info$limit / 4))) } else { cat_success(sprintf(‚Äú‚úì Quota sufficient (%d vCPUs)‚Äù, quota_info$limit)) } } User-Facing Documentation README: markdown ### Scaling Beyond Quota Limits staRburst automatically handles AWS quota limitations: Wave-based execution: - request 100 workers quota allows 25 - staRburst runs 4 waves 25 workers - work completes, just takes slightly longer - manual intervention needed Automatic quota increases: - staRburst offer request quota increases - Usually approved within 1-24 hours - Future runs use full parallelism Manual quota check: handles single biggest UX failure mode gracefully proactively. text: Stops running ECS tasks session ends Deletes S3 session files force = TRUE option Tracks ECS task ARNs session manifest reliable cleanup Verification step ensures resources properly released Prevents orphaned workers runaway costs Create sessions starburst_session() Submit tasks disconnect: session$submit(expr) Reattach later starburst_session_attach(session_id) Check progress anytime: session$status() Workers stay running absolute timeout (default 24h) Accessing CloudWatch Logs (console CLI) Tasks stuck pending (quota, IAM, network) Permission errors (ECS, S3, ECR) High costs runaway workers Package installation failures issue includes symptoms, diagnosis, solutions, prevention Credential management (IAM roles, profiles, STS) S3 bucket security (encryption, versioning, policies) Network isolation (VPCs, security groups, endpoints) Cost controls budget alerts Audit logging (CloudTrail, CloudWatch) Compliance considerations (HIPAA, GDPR)

title: starburst 0.3.0 (2026-02-12)
text: New safe_system() wrapper using processx::run() Command whitelist validation Automatic argument escaping (shell expansion) Prevents code execution via Docker/AWS CLI parameters 25 new security regression tests Hard limit 500 workers per cluster (prevents accidental runaway costs) Validation plan() time helpful error messages Clear guidance requesting quota increases needed Estimated cost validation worker launch ECR password longer exposed process listings Uses stdin Docker login (command line arguments) Credentials never visible ps aux output Temporary files cleaned immediately use

title: starburst 0.3.0 (2026-02-12)
text: ETag-based optimistic locking concurrent updates Automatic retry exponential backoff conflicts Ensures manifest updates lost multiple workers update simultaneously Critical detached sessions many workers Exponential backoff jitter AWS operations Retries throttling, timeouts, 5xx errors automatically Configurable retry limits (default 3 attempts) Specialized retry wrappers: with_s3_retry(), with_ecs_retry(), with_ecr_retry() Reduces job failures temporary AWS service issues New starburst_error() helper rich error messages Every error includes relevant context (quota limits, resources, regions) Actionable solutions provided (just ‚Äúsomething failed‚Äù) Links troubleshooting guide detailed help Specialized errors: quota_error(), permission_error(), task_failure_error()

title: starburst 0.3.0 (2026-02-12)
text: starburst_session() - Create detached session long-running jobs starburst_session_attach() - Reattach existing session starburst_session_list() - List active sessions session$submit() - Submit tasks detached session session$status() - Check session progress task states session$collect() - Retrieve completed results session$cleanup() - Stop workers clean resources
